4 vanilla beans (secondary, 5 days)
3 oz. cinnamon sticks (secondary, 5 days)
YEAST
1 pkg Fermentis US-05, White Labs WLP001, or Wyeast 1056
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gallons (19 L)
Original Gravity: 1.061
Final Gravity: 1.013
ABV: 6.20%
IBU: 39
SRM: 32
directions:
Directions:
Target a mash thickness of about 1.5 quarts of water per pound of grain (a 3:1 liquor/grist ratio by weight). Mash at 153°F (67°C), adding the king cake at mash-in, until enzymatic conversion is complete, about 60 minutes. Conduct a mash out at 168°F (76°C). Sparge with 170°F (77°C) water. Conduct a 75-minute boil, following the timed additions listed in the ingredients section. Any kettle finings, such as Irish Moss, can be added in the last 15 minutes. After the boil, chill the wort rapidly to 66°F (19°C), let the break material settle, rack to a fermenter, pitch the yeast, and aerate thoroughly. Ferment around 67°F (19°C) for 3 days and then allow to temperature to rise to 70°F (21°C) until the yeast drops clear (14 days maximum). With healthy yeast, fermentation should be complete in a week but don’t rush it. Rack to a keg or secondary fermenter and add the cinnamon sticks and vanilla beans in separate “dry hop” bags that can be removed when the desired flavor levels of each are reached (taste daily!). Rack to a keg and force carbonate or rack to a bottling bucket, add priming sugar, and bottle. Target a carbonation level of 2.5 volumes (5 g/L) of CO2.

description:
This beer recipe is featured in the book Brewing Eclectic IPA by Dick Cantwell. Want access to exclusive homebrew recipes? Start your 30-day free trial AHA membership (no payment info required)!
Move over pumpkin-spice latte ales because this isn't your average pumpkin beer recipe! Cantwell uses additions of pineapple sage for a fruity, exotic character, while sage leaves create an almost minty quality.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
GRAIN BILL
11 lb (5 kg) American 2-row malt
1 lb (454 g) Weyermann Munich malt
8 oz (225 g) Weyermann Dark Munich malt
4 oz (112 g) Weyermann Carahell malt
2 oz (56 g) Weyermann Carafa® II malt
HOPS
1.75 oz (50 g) Columbus (14% AA) @ 90 min
1.0 oz (28 g) Mosaic (12.25% AA) @ 2 min
1.0 oz (28 g) Zythos (10.9% AA) @ 2 min
1.5 oz (42 g) Mosaic (12.25% AA) @ whirlpool
1.5 oz (42 g) Zythos (10.9% AA) @ whirlpool
ADDITIONAL INGREDIENTS
8 oz (225 g) unspiced pumpkin puree @ mash
8 oz (225 g) unspiced pumpkin puree @ kettle
6 oz (170 g) unspiced pumpkin puree @ fermentor
0.5 oz (14 g) pineapple sage leaves
YEAST
Imperial Yeast A07 Flagship
Specifications:
Yield: 5 US gallons (19 L)
Original Gravity: 1.070 (16.5° P)
Final Gravity: 1.020 (4.75° P)
ABV: 6.60%
IBU: 57
SRM: 9.89
directions:
Directions:
Mash 60 minutes at 153° F (67° C) with 8 oz. (225 g) pumpkin puree (thinned with water). Boil 90 minutes with 8 oz. (225 g) pumpkin puree (dilute with wort and reintroduce). Add pineapple sage leaves at whirlpool. Ferment with 6 oz. (170 g) pumpkin puree (diluted with wort) until terminal, then transfer to secondary. Condition at 35° F (2° C) 1 week until bright. Carbonate to 2.5 volumes (4.9 g/L) CO2.

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the March/April 2019 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
My gluten-free version of this uncommon style has a striking color, savory aroma, and malty flavors with mild caramel, subtle chocolate, and fruit esters. Oak adds vanilla and complexity, even if it’s not strictly to style.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
MALTS AND SUGARS
6.5 lb (2.95 kg) pale millet malt
5.0 lb (2.27 kg) Munich millet malt
8 oz (227 g) rolled oats
8 oz (227 g) chocolate millet malt
1.5 lb (680 g) maltodextrin, end of boil
1 lb (454 g) D-45 candi syrup, end of boil
HOPS
1 oz (28 g) Fuggle, 4.5% a.a. @ 60 min
YEAST
2 sachets Fermentis SafAle S-04
ADDITIONAL ITEMS
0.25 oz (7–10 mL) SebAmyl L beta amylase
1 lb (454 g) rice hulls
0.2 oz (6 g) yeast nutrient
2 oz (57 g) medium-toast oak cubes
Specifications:
Yield: 4 US gal (15.1 L)
Original Gravity: 1.091 (21.8°P)
Final Gravity: 1.028 (7.1°P)
ABV: 8.20%
IBU: 22
SRM: 21
directions:
Directions:
Use a decantation mash for a dry beer. Conduct a beta-glucan rest at 104°F (40°C). Raise to 150°F (66°C) for 45 minutes. Save clear, enzyme-rich wort after the grist settles. Heat cereal to 200°F (93°C) for 15 minutes to gelatinize—don’t scorch it. Recombine to 150°F (66°C) and add beta amylase and rice hulls. Hold one hour, lauter, and sparge. Collect 6 gallons (22.7 L) of wort, and boil to yield 4 gallons (15.1 L), about 3 hours. Add a few grams of yeast nutrient and ferment at 64°F (18°C). The cool fermentation suppresses boozy flavors, but some esters are desirable. This beer may finish drier than expected. After primary fermentation, transfer beer to a secondary carboy with the oak cubes and condition for 28 days before bottling or kegging.

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the March/April 2019 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
My dad gave me my first homebrew kit. To say thanks, I would always make him an amber ale or red ale when he would come to visit. But after I went gluten free, getting a similar red hue and chewy malt flavor into a beer proved challenging.
Nonetheless, my gluten-free version won Ground Breaker’s 1st Annual Pacific Northwest Gluten-Free Homebrew Competition. It went on to score a 36 in the First Round of the National Homebrew Competition and recently won a blue ribbon at the Oregon State Fair. It’s a tasty beer and, most importantly, Dad loves it.
If the color turns out less red than desired, add small amounts of D-90 candi syrup to add color.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
MALTS
10 lbs (4.54 kg) Grouse Pale Millet Malt
1.5 lb. (680 g) Grouse Munich Millet Malt
1 lb. (454 g) Grouse Roasted Caramillet
12 oz. (340 g) Grouse Crystal Millet 10L
12 oz (340 g) Eckert James’ Rice Malt
8 oz (227 g) Grouse Buckwheat Malt
8 oz (227 g) Eckert Crystal Rice Malt 15L
4 oz (113 g) Grouse Chocolate Millet
HOPS
0.25 oz (7 g) CTZ @ 60 min (13 IBU)
0.5 oz (14 g) Cascade, 7% a.a. @ 10 min
0.5 oz (14 g) Centennial, 10% a.a. @ 10 min
0.5 oz (14 g) Cascade, 7% a.a., whirlpool 20 min
0.5 oz (14 g) Centennial, 10% a.a., whirlpool 20 min
0.5 oz (14 g) Amarillo, 8% a.a., whirlpool 20 min
0.5 oz (14 g) Simcoe, 12% a.a., whirlpool 20 min
YEAST
Fermentis SafAle US-05 (dry yeast is gluten free)
ADDITIONAL ITEMS
20 mL (0.7 oz) Termamyl alpha amylase
1 lb (454 g) rice hulls
20 mL (0.7 oz) SebAmyl L alpha amylase
2 Tbsp (30 mL) Wyeast yeast nutrient
Specifications:
Yield: 5 US gallons (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.068 (16.6°P)
Final Gravity: 1.013 (3.3°P)
ABV: 7.30%
IBU: 44
SRM: 15
directions:
Directions:
Reverse step mash 30 min. at 185°F (85°C) with 20 mL Termamyl (a heat-tolerant alpha enzyme) for gelatinization. Then rest for 60–90 min. at 155°F (68.3°C) with 20 mL SebAmyl L for saccharification. Recirculate until wort is clear and passes a starch test. Sparge, boil 60 min., cool to 65°F (18.3°C), transfer, and ferment at 65°F (18.3°C) until gravity stabilizes.

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the March/April 2019 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
From Mike L.: This is my standard sahti recipe, adapted for typical homebrewing equipment. I have refined it based on my tastes, various brewing experiments, and conversations with sahti masters. While not a classic family recipe, it’s a good example of homebrewed sahti today.
I brew this ale with the same gear I use for modern ales, and I have included options for ingredients easily found outside Finland. I have also streamlined the mashing procedure: with a heated mash tun, the brew day can be over in less than five hours. I haven’t included strict fermentation guidelines; this will depend on the yeast you use.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
MALTS
14 lb (7 kg) Pilsner or Vienna malt
4.8 lb (2.4 kg) Munich malt
1.2 lb (0.6 kg) Kaljamallas (Finnish dark rye malt) or caramel rye malt
OTHER INGREDIENTS
0.4 oz (12 g) juniper branches or juniper berries
YEAST
0.8 oz (25 g) fresh baker's yeast, 0.3 oz (10 g) dry baker's yeast or kveik yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 US gallons (20 L)
Original Gravity: 1.097 (23°P)
Final Gravity: 1.034 (8.5°P)
ABV: 8%
SRM: 17
directions:
Directions:
Mash the malts at 140°F (60°C) for 45 minutes using 1.1 qt. water per pound of grain (2.3 L/kg). If using juniper, mix the branches or berries into the mash. Raise the temperature to 158°F (70°C), and hold 45 minutes, and then raise to 176°F (80°C) for the final 15 minutes. Recirculate until the wort runs clear. Sparge with 176 to 194°F (80 to 90°C) water to collect 5 gal. (20 L). If using an immersion chiller, sanitize it in the hot wort. Chill the wort to fermentation temperature. If using baker’s yeast, dissolve the fresh yeast in a small amount of cold water, or rehydrate dry yeast in 104°F (40°C) water. Pour wort into the fermenter, add yeast, let ferment, and keep at fermentation temperature until the yeast is finishing its work. Depending on the yeast and temperature, this usually takes 1 to 3 days. When the sahti still tastes sweetish but is no longer cloying, lower the fermentation temperature. If unsure about the timing of this transfer, you can check whether the gravity is in the range 1.034 to 1.038 (8.5 to 9.5°P). Cold condition the sahti for 7 to 10 days, and then rack to storage containers. The ale is ready immediately after racking. Store cool at all times.

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the March/April 2019 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
This beer was initially conceived as an attempt at one of my first and favorite craft-style ales from way back in the 1980s: Redback from Matilda Bay Brewing in Australia. I have fond memories of quaffing bottles of Redback during my undergraduate years at Cal Poly, San Luis Obispo. That beer did not contain sugar but was instead a down-under version of Bavarian wheat ale. My recipe is somewhat drier due to the cane sugar, but with high carbonation, low hopping, and Bavarian wheat yeast to add subtle hints of clove and banana, it is exceptionally refreshing.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
MALTS
4.5 lb (2.04 kg ) home-malted wheat
4.5 lb (2.04 kg) Briess two-row pale malt
12 oz (340 g) raw organic cane sugar (optional)
HOPS
2 oz (57 g) homegrown Sterling 2.3% a.a. @ 60 min
YEAST
White Labs WLP380 Hefeweizen IV Ale Yeast (2 L starter)
WATER
Soft: use 1 g/gal. CaCl2 added to reverse osmosis water
OTHER INGREDIENTS
6.5 oz (177 g) destrose to prime to 3.25 vol (6.5 g/L) CO2
Specifications:
Yield: 5.5 US gallons (20.8 L)
Original Gravity: 1.050 (12.5°P)
Final Gravity: 1.007 (1.8°P)
ABV: 5.70%
IBU: 13
SRM: 3
Boil Time: 60 minutes
Efficiency: 75%
directions:
Directions:
Adjust your mill for the average kernel size of your home-malted wheat. My wheat kernels were quite a bit smaller than those of commercial malt, and my first brew with home-malted wheat got too coarse a crush—I got a great sparge but a lousy yield. With subsequent batches, not only did my level of modification improve, but double milling the wheat malt on the finest mill setting gave me much better results without any need for rice hulls. Mash grains for 20 minutes at 125°F (52°C). Raise to 140°F (60°C) and hold 30 minutes. Raise to 152°F (67°C) and hold 40 minutes. It’s probably a good idea to do a starch test to ensure conversion. When it passes, mash out at 168°F (76°C). Fly sparge with 168°F (76°C) water. Boil 60 minutes, adding homegrown hops one hour before flameout. Be sure to take an initial gravity reading. You may not need to add sugar, but if your initial is running low, add cane sugar to the boil as needed to compensate. I got a pre-boil gravity of 1.040 (10°P) and added 12 oz. (340 g) of cane sugar to bring the gravity up to 1.044 (11°P), which gave an original gravity of 1.050 (12°P) after boil losses. Keep in mind that my finishing gravity of 1.007 (1.75°P) is based on using the sugar addition; without sugar, expect an FG closer to 1.010 (2.5°P). Jar up priming gyle or speise 5 minutes before the end of the boil (if using). Chill wort to 64°F (18°C) and pitch a strong starter. Ferment for three days at 64°F (18°C) or until high kräusen, then allow the beer to free rise to 68°F (20°) and hold this temperature until fermentation is complete. Prime with gyle and bottle in sturdy glass bottles. Keep these at 70°F (21°C) for a week or until they begin to clear. Store at cellar temperatures for two weeks.
addition:
Extract Version
Not recommended. You will likely need the diastatic power of the full amount of domestic two-row for complete conversion.

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the March/April 2019 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
This Belgian-style recipe is courtesy of Amahl Turczyn with a variation by Kurt Elia. If you've never had the chance to try the Chimay Dorée Trappist Ale brewed by Belgium's Scoutmount Abbey, this is your opportunity to bring it home!
ingredients:
Ingredients:
MALTS AND SUGARS
6 lb (2.72 kg) Dingermans Pilsner Malt
12 oz (340 g) Dingermans 6°L Cara 8 malt
8 oz (227 g) Blegian wheat malt
8 oz (227 g) white sugar @ 10 min
HOPS
1 oz (28 g) Saaz 4% a.a. @ 60 min
0.5 oz (14 g) Hallertau 4.8% a.a. @ 30 min
ADDITIONAL ITEMS
1 oz (28 g) ground bitter orange peel @ 10 min
0.5 oz (14 g) ground coriander seed @ 10 min
6.5 oz (184 g) candi sugar to prime (if bottling)
1 tablet Whirlfloc @ 15 min
YEAST
White Labs WLP500 Monastery Ale Yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5.5 US gal (20.8 L)
Original Gravity: 1.040 (10°P)
Final Gravity: 1.004 (1°P)
ABV: 4.60%
IBU: 20
SRM: 3
Efficiency: 75%
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 147° F (64° C) for 75 minutes. Mash out at 168° F (76° C) for 10 minutes. Sparge, boil 90 minutes and add hops, sugar and spices at stated intervals. Chill to 64° F (18° C), oxygenate and pitch a strong starter of yeast. Ferment at 72° F (22° C) for the first 4 days, then at 66° F (19° C) until fermentation begins to slow, then chill to 50° F (10° C) and cellar for 4 weeks. Rack clear beer onto priming sugar (blending thoroughly), bottle and condition beer for 8 days at 75° F (24° C). Cellar beer for 4-6 weeks.
addition:
KURT’S VARIATION
Replace 12 oz. (340 g) Dingemans 6°L Cara 8 malt with 10 oz. (283 g) Briess Caramel 10°L malt, replace 8 oz. (227 g) Belgian wheat malt with 8 oz. (227 g) Weyermann wheat malt, and replace 8 oz. (227 g) white sugar with 8 oz. (227 g) Simplicity Candi Syrup plus 6 oz. (170 g) table sugar. Prepare a 750 mL stir-plate starter of White Labs WLP500 Monastery Ale Yeast prior to brew day. Postpone the 30-minute Hallertau hop addition to 15 minutes before the end of the boil.
Conduct a single infusion mash at 149°F (65°C) for 75 minutes at a pH of 5.3, and fly sparge to collect 6.5 gal. (24.6 L) of wort. Add candi syrup and sugar to the hot wort for a pre-boil specific gravity of 1.036 (9°P). Boil 60 minutes, adding hops and spices (remember to add the Hallertau at 15 min. instead of 30 min.), to yield 5.5 gal. (20.8 L) of 1.041 (10.2°P) wort.
Chill, oxygenate, and pitch at 64°F (17.8°C). Ferment at 71°F (21.7°C) for 2 days and then at 69–71°F (20.6–21.7°C) until fermentation slows. Raise to 72°F (22.2°C) for a couple of days until specific gravity reaches 1.004 (1°P). Rack to secondary and fine with 0.25 oz. (7 g) Polyclar mixed with 350 mL (12 fl. oz.) boiled water. Hold at 65°F (18.3°C) for one day, and then slowly lower temperature to 35°F (1.7°C) at a rate of about 4°F (2.2°C) per day.
Rack clear beer to a keg and hold at 35°F (1.7°C) under 15 psi (1,034 mbar) for 9–10 days or until carbonated to 3 vol. (6 g/L) CO2. If you can wait, let the beer cold condition for a month in the keg after racking and carbonating. The patient brewer will be richly rewarded with a smooth, bright beer.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Big Timber Brewing Porter from Big Timber Brewing in Elkins, West Virginia. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This well balanced, yet complex porter from Big Timber Brewing Company derives all of its flavor from loads of specialty malts. It was one of three beers available when the brewery opened in 2014. The recipe has remained virtually unchanged, and this beer and can only be found in West Virginia!
ingredients:
Ingredients:
7.5 lb (3.4 kg) 2-row malt
1.75 lb (0.79 kg) White Wheat
1.75 lb (0.79 kg) Brown malt
8 oz (0.23 kg) Coffee malt
8 oz (0.23 kg) Extra Dark Crystal malt
8 oz (0.23 kg) Chocolate malt
0.63 oz (18 g) Magnum hops, 11% a.a. (80 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) EKG hops, 5% a.a. (20 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) EKG hops, 5% a.a. (5 min)
English Ale Yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.065
Final Gravity: 1.015
ABV: 6.50%
IBU: 33
SRM: 28
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 150° F (66° C) for 60 minutes. Add calcium carbonate to reach mash pH ~5.4. Boil 90 minutes. Ferment at 68° F (20° C).

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Crow Peak Brewing Co. Pile ‘O Dirt Porter from Crow Peak Brewing Co. in Spearfish, South Dakota. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This beer was named Pile 'O Dirt because of the ridiculous amount of dirt Crow Peak Brewing had to build their original brewery on to get them out of the flood plain. This porter is very dark in color with a nice tan head and complexity due to the variety of specialty malts used.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
9 lb (4.08 kg) Briess Pale Ale malt
1.5 lb (0.68 kg) Briess Bonlander Munich malt (10L)
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Briess Chocolate malt
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Briess Carapils malt
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Briess Extra Special malt
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Briess Blackprinz malt
0.5 oz (14 g) Perle hops, 8.2 % a.a. (first wort)
0.3 oz Willamette hops, 4.5% a.a. (10 min)
0.3 oz Willamette hops, 4.5% a.a. (whirlpool)
Pacific Northwest Ale yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5.5 gal (20.8 L)
Original Gravity: 1.062
Final Gravity: 1.015
ABV: 5.50%
IBU: 20
SRM: 35
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 156° F (69° C) for 60 minutes. 60 minute boil. Ferment at 63° F (17° C).

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Earth Rider Brewery Precious Material Helles from Earth Rider Brewery in Superior, Wisconsin. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This export helles from Earth Rider Brewery was inspired by Augustiner Edelstoff, which founder Tim Nelson fell in love with on a trip to Bavaria. It's alcohol percentage is above what a standard helles would be, and the hop character is also slightly elevated compared to a typical helles.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
25 lb (11.3 kg) Bohemian Pilsner malt
3 lb (1.36 kg) Vienna malt
1.5 lb (0.68 kg) Munich malt
0.75 lb (0.34 kg) CaraHell malt
4 oz (113 g) German Tettnang hops (90 min)
2.5 oz (71 g) German Tettnang hops (15 min)
German Lager yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 15 gal (56.8 L)
Original Gravity: 1.052 (12.8 P)
Final Gravity: 1.010 (2.6 P)
ABV: 5.50%
IBU: 29
SRM: 3
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 152° F (67°C). Ferment at 52° F (11° C) until gravity reaches 1.018 (4.5 P), then raise fermentation temperature to 60° F (16° C) for diacetyl rest.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Reuben’s Brews Robust Porter from Reuben's Brews in Seattle, Washington. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
One of Reuben's Brews year round beers, this robust porter was one of the first beers brewed when they opened in 2012. Brewmaster Adam Robbings came up with the recipe as a homebrewer and he won gold the first three competitions with the very first batch!
ingredients:
Ingredients:
7 lb (3.18 kg) Maris Otter
1 lb (0.45 kg) Caramel 40
0.25 lb (0.11 kg) Caramel 80
1 lb (0.45 kg) Munich Malt
1 lb (0.45 kg) Pale Chocolate Malt
0.25 lb (0.11 kg) British Black Malt
0.25 lb (0.11 kg) Carapils
1.25 oz (38 g) Cascade hops, 5.5% a.a. (60 min)
0.75 oz (21 g) Cascade hops, 5.5% a.a. (10 min)
American Ale yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.059
Final Gravity: 1.013
ABV: 5.90%
IBU: 30
SRM: 28
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 152-153° F (67° C). Ferment at 67° F (19° C).

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Whetstone Station Brewery Whetstoner Session IPA from Whetstone Station Restaurant & Brewery in Brattleboro, Vermont. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This bright and delicious session IPA from Whetstone Craft Beers features Simcoe, Amarillo and Citra hops. While it's hazy, aromatic and full of flavor, at just 4.5% ABV this crisp beer is perfect for when you've got thirst that needs quenching.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
7 lb (3.18 kg) Pale (2-row) malt
1 lb (0.45 kg) White Wheat
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Crystal 30 malt
2.25 oz (64 g) Amarillo hops, 9.2% (whirlpool)
1.50 oz (42 g) Simcoe hops, 13% a.a. (whirlpool)
0.75 oz (21 g) Amarillo hops, 9.2% a.a. (dry hop)
0.75 oz (21 g) Citra hops, 13.4% a.a. (dry hop)
0.75 oz (21 g) Simcoe hops, 13% a.a. (dry hop)
American Ale yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.045
Final Gravity: 1.01
ABV: 4.60%
IBU: 36
SRM: 4.8
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 150° F (66° C). Sparge at 168° F (76° C). Boil 90 minutes, following hop additions as listed in the ingredients section. Ferment at 65° F (18° C) or within the range of the yeast used. After fermentation, add dry hops and let sit 2 days. Carbonate to 2.3 volumes of CO2.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Strangeways Brewing Martian Spring Biere de Mars from Strangeways Brewing in Richmond, Virginia. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Martian Spring from Strangeways Brewing is based on the classic Bière de Garde style, but with an extra kick of hops to make it more of a Bière de Mars. This might be a classic style, but American hops and dry-hopping make this a pretty unique beer!
ingredients:
Ingredients:
4.44 lb (2.01 kg) Pilsner malt
3.19 lb (1.45 kg) Wheat malt
1.63 lb (0.74 kg) Optic malt
1 lb (0.45 kg) Caramel Pilsner malt
15 oz (0.43 kg) Flaked Oats
0.6 oz (17 g) UK Target hops, 9.8% a.a. (60 min)
0.4 oz (11 g) Simcoe hops, 11% a.a. (30 min)
0.4 oz (11 g) Citra hops, 12% a.a. (30 min)
6.5 oz (184 g) White Sugar (5 min)
0.4 oz (11 g) Citra hops, 12% a.a. (0 min)
0.4 oz. (11 g) Galena hops, 13.9% a.a. (0 min)
1.4 oz (40 g) Centennial hops, 10% a.a. (dry hop)
1.0 oz (28 g) Simcoe hops, 11% a.a. (dry hop)
0.6 oz (17 g) Citra hops, 12% a.a. (dry hop)
Bière de Garde yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.061 (15 P)
Final Gravity: 1.013 (3.2)
ABV: 6.20%
IBU: 40
directions:
Directions:
If possible, conduct a stepped mash with 20 minute holds at the following temperatures:  122° F, 144° F, 156° F, and 168° F. Alternatively, you can do a single infusion mash for 60 minutes at 156° F and then sparge at 168° F. Continue with a standard 60-minute boil, adding hops and sugar according to the ingredients section. Start fermentation at 72° F, the let the temperature free rise. Don’t panic if temperatures get over 90° F! Biere de Garde yeast can be finicky sometimes and just quit fermenting if you try to cool the temperature. Once fermentation is complete, transfer to secondary. For best results, age your beer in or on red wine oak barrels or oak chips. The touch of red wine character gives the beer a lovely, subtle character that works well with the yeast and hop characteristics. Allow beer to age for at least 8 weeks, perhaps up to 12 weeks, bringing the temperature down to 45-50° F for the last 2-3 weeks. After aging, simply continue with bottling/kegging as usual. Brewer’s note: this beer requires patience and attention to temperature! Sure, let the fermentation temperature go as high as it wants, but then follow the aging program above for the best results. Biere de Garde is a funny yeast to work with, but its results can be beautiful. In fact, this is the perfect beer to brew in December, bottle in February, and drink in March. Cheers!

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Red Rock Brewing Black Bier from Red Rock Brewing in Park City, Utah. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This beer recipe was taken from the book Session Beers: Brewing for Flavor and Balance by Jennifer Talley.
This German-style dark lager from Red Rock Brewery is a classic schwarzbier that won a gold medal at the 2010 Great American Beer Festival. It's unusually dark color is gained from four different malts and very light hopping that make it a sessionable black lager.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
7.0 lbs (3.18 kg) Pilsner malt
12 oz (340 g) Munich malt 10° L
5 oz (140 g) dehusked black malt
1.5 oz (43 g) roast malt
0.75 oz (21 g) Tettnang (4% AA) @ 60 min
0.75 oz (21 g) Tettnang (4% AA) @ 30 min
1.5 oz (43 g) Hallertauer Mittelfrüh (4% AA) @ whirlpool
Lager yeast (2124 Wyeast)
Adjust reverse osmosis water pH with lactic acid. No calcium needed.
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.040 (10 P)
Final Gravity: 1.009 (2.3 P)
ABV: 4%
IBU: 28
directions:
Directions:
Mash as normal, rest at 148-149° F (64.4-65° C), thin mash. Ferment at 48-49° F (8.9-9.4° C). Once primary fermentation is complete, rack the beer off the yeast and age in the coldest place you have, 33-36° F (0.5-2° C) is optimal. Since it’s only 4% ABV do not cool below 33° F (0.5° C). Rack again into a Cornelius keg or bottle. Carbonate to 2.5 vol CO2.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Atlas Brew Works Rowdy Rye Ale from Atlas Brew Works in Washington, Washington, D.C.. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Atlas Brew Works in Washington D.C. created this hop-forward rye ale that is both fun and aggressive. Using a large amount of specialty malts and three hop varieties, it is sure to get rye ale lovers' attention.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
6 lb (2.72 kg) Briess Pilsen malt
1.5 lb (0.68 kg) Briess Rye malt
0.8 lb (0.36 kg) Weyermann Carared
0.8 lb (0.36 kg) Briess Aromatic malt
0.4 lb (0.18 kg) Briess Victory malt
0.4 lb (0.18 kg) Briess Carapils malt
0.2 lb (91 g) Briess Midnight Wheat
0.32 oz (9 g) Bravo hops (90 min)
0.48 oz (13.5 g) Zythos hops (20 min)
1.23 oz (35 g) Centennial hops (5 min)
0.63 oz (18 g) Centennial hops (dry hop)
0.63 oz (18 g) Zythos hops (dry hop)
American Ale yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.057 (14 P)
ABV: 6.20%
IBU: 50
SRM: 19
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 68° C (154° F). Conduct a 90 minute boil. Optional water profile: Using carbon filtered DC tap water, add 1.5 g of calcium sulfate and 1.5 g calcium chloride to the mash, as well as 2 mL of food grade 85% phosphoric acid to the sparge.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Jester King Brewery Figlet Farmhouse Amber Ale from Jester King Brewery in Austin, Texas. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This dry farmhouse ale called Figlet is a real Texas gem! Jester King Brewery stayed true to Texas style by incorporating locally-sourced cold-smoked figs into the recipe.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
6 lb (2.72 kg) Munich II
1.75 lb (0.79 kg) Pilsner malt
0.5 lb (0.23 kg)Rolled Oats
0.5 oz (14 g) ZYthos hops, 9.6% a.a. (60 min)
Mixed Culture or French Saison Yeast
Cold-smoked figs
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.045
Final Gravity: 1
ABV: 6.40%
IBU: 28
SRM: 8.5
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 152° F (67° C). Ferment according to the yeast’s specifications. After primary fermentation, rack to secondary with cold-smoked figs.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Roadhouse Brewing Co. Family Vacation Cream Ale from Roadhouse Brewing Co. in Jackson Hole, Wyoming. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Family Vacation was originally brewed to quench the thirst of locals coming back from a day of skiing and was inspired by a wildly popular Midwestern brewed cream ale. Over the past 5 years, Roadhouse Brewing C. has taken the liberty of adjusting the recipe to ensure it's always crushable!
ingredients:
Ingredients:
26 lb (11.8 kg) Pilsner malt
3 lb (1.36 kg) Flaked Barley
1 oz (28 g) Saaz hops, 3.4% a.a. (60 min)
1 oz (28 g) Saaz hops. 3.4% a.a. (30 min)
1 oz (28 g) Comet hops, 9.5% a.a. (5 min)
1 oz (28 g) Saaz hops, 3.4% a.a. (5 min)
Whirlfloc (10 min)
Yeast Nutrient (10 min)
American Ale yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 15 gal (56.8 kg)
Original Gravity: 1.044 (11 P)
Final Gravity: 1.007 (1.75 P)
ABV: 4.90%
IBU: 11
SRM: 3
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 152° F (67° C) with a thin grist/water ratio. Boil 60 minutes. Ferment at 69° F (21° C) (if possible, raise temperature to 72° F (22° C) when gravity has reached 1.012/3 or when terminal for a diacetyl rest). Cool to 32° F (0° C) (step cooling will reduce chill haze). Add fining agent of your choice and rest at 32° F (0° C) for 3-7 days or until clarity is to your liking. Carbonate to 2.5-2.6 volumes CO2 and enjoy! For fun, you can dry hop or add fruit to this beer. Roadhouse Brewing has done both! If fruiting, we recommend adding fruit during fermentation to ensure all sugars are consumed before packaging. If dry hopping, pick your favorite and go light, as this is a delicate beer and a little goes a long way!

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Tennessee Valley Brewing Co. DIVARTY Redlegs from Tennessee Valley Brewing Company in Clarksville, Tennessee. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
DIVARTY Red Legs from Tennessee Valley Brewing Company is named in honor of brave Division Artillery soldiers. This is an Irish red ale that's really easy drinking with slight malty flavor, a soft touch of caramel and lightly roasty finish.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
8 lb (3.63 kg) 2-row malt
5 oz (142 g) Caramel malt, 60L
4 oz (113 g) Caramel malt, 120L
4 oz (113 g) Chocolate malt, 350L
1.25 oz (35 g) Willamette hops, 5.5% a.a. (60 min)
Irish Moss (10 min)
Safale US-05 yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.046
Final Gravity: 1.011
ABV: 4.50%
IBU: 24.7
SRM: 14.1
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 153° F (67° C). Ferment at 68° F for 1 week. Rack into secondary for 1 week. Carbonate to 2.3 volumes of CO2.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of IMBĪB Custom Brews Nevada Weisse from IMBĪB Custom Brews in Sparks, Nevada. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This low ABV, high flavor beer from Nevada’s IMBIB Custom Brews is sure to refresh the drinker and help reminisce of fun summer months.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
4 lb (1.81 kg) Pilsner malt
2.25 lb (1.02 kg) Malted Wheat
Wyeast 3191 Berliner Weisse Blend
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.035
Final Gravity: 1.006
ABV: 3.80%
SRM: 2
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 148° F (74° C) for 45 minutes. Boil wort for 60 minutes. Ferment at 70° F (21° C) for 2 weeks. Transfer to secondary fermentation vessel and maintain temperature at 70° F (21° C) until desired acidity level is reached. If using a second generation (or beyond) yeast blend, please note that acidity level will likely be reached more quickly than first generation, and flavor/aroma profile may evolve each generation.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Biloxi Brewing Company Pale Ale from Biloxi Brewing Company in Biloxi, Mississippi. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This is Biloxi Brewing Company's sessionable pale ale that bursts with grapefruit flavors and aromas from the generous amount of Citra hops used, especially in the dry hop addition.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
6.47 lb (2.93 kg) Pale 2-row malt
1 lb (0.45 kg) Munch malt
12.4 oz (0.35 kg) Cara-Pils/Dextrine malt
10.1 oz (0.28 kg) Crystal 40 malt
0.42 oz (12 g) Citra hops, 14% a.a. (60 min)
0.42 oz (12 g) Cascade hops, 6.3% a.a. (15 min)
0.42 oz (12 g) Citra hops, 12.2% a.a. (15 min)
0.42 oz (12 g) Cascade hops (whirlpool)
0.42 oz (12 g) Citra hops (whirlpool)
0.83 oz (23 g) Citra hops (dry hop)
0.42 oz (12 g) Cascade hops (dry hop)
Safale US-05 American ale yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.049 (12.2 P)
Final Gravity: 1.009 (2.4 P)
ABV: 5.20%
IBU: 37
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 150° F (66° C) for 75 minutes. Mash out at 168° F for 10 minutes. Conduct a 60 minute boil, following ingredient additions as listed. Primary fermetation at 67° F (19° C), then age at 65° F (18° C) for 30 days.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Holy City Brewing Pluff Mud Porter from Holy City Brewing in North Charleston, South Carolina. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Holy City Brewing's Pluff Mud Porter presents (and smells) like a classic porter, with subtle chocolate notes and a silky finish, but the medium body and tame ABV keep it refreshing at all times. Enjoy this throughout the year, in or out of the marsh.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
6.6 lb (2.99 kg) Pale malt
2.4 lb (1.09 kg) Crystal 20
1.2 lb (0.54 kg) Crystal 60
1.2 lb (0.54 kg) Munich II
9.5 oz (0.27 kg) Carafa
0.78 oz (22 g) Northern Brewer hops, 8.5% a.a. (60 min)
British Ale yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.061 (15 P)
Final Gravity: 1.021 (5.3 P)
ABV: 5.50%
IBU: 21
SRM: 24
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 65° C (149° F) for 45 minutes. Ferment at yeast’s specifications.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Red Door Brewing Company New England IPA from Red Door Brewing Company in Albuquerque, New Mexico. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This juicy and hazy India pale ale from Red Door Brewing Co. features an intense tropical fruit and floral nose. This is a perfect choice for warm weather.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
7.45 lb (3.38 kg) 2-row
3.77 lb (1.71 kg) Malted White Wheat
2.18 lb (0.99 kg) Flaked Oats
0.2 oz (6 g) Citra hops, 13.7% a.a. (FWH)
0.2 oz (6 g) Mosaic hops, 10.7% a.a. (FWH)
0.2 oz (6 g) El Dorado, 15% a.a.  (FWH)
1.3 oz (37 g) Citra hops, 13.7% a.a. (whirlpool)
1.3 oz (37 g) Mosaic hops, 10.7% a.a. (whirlpool)
1.3 oz (37 g) El Dorado, 15% a.a. (whirlpool)
1.3 oz (37 g) Citra hops, 13.7% a.a. (dry hop #1)
1.3 oz (37 g) Mosaic hops, 10.7% a.a. (dry hop #1)
1.3 oz (37 g) El Dorado, 15% a.a. (dry hop #1)
1.3 oz (37 g) Citra hops, 13.7% a.a. (dry hop #2)
1.3 oz (37 g) Mosaic hops, 10.7% a.a. (dry hop #2)
1.3 oz (37 g) El Dorado, 15% a.a. (dry hop #2)
London ale III
0.32 oz (9 g) Calcium Chloride
2.21 ml Phosphoric Acid (85%)
0.32 oz (9 g) Calcium Sulfate (gypsum)
16 ml Zinc, yeast nutrient (15 min)
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.066 (16.2 P)
Final Gravity: 1.014 (3.7 P)
ABV: 7.10%
IBU: 69
SRM: 4.3
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 154° F with a girst ratio of 2.5 qt/lb. Mash in all the grain, mixing in all the calcium chloride and 0.6 mL of phosphoric acid. Rest for one hour, vorlauf for 30 minutes. Run off wort into kettle and add first wort hop (FWH) additions as well as 0.32 oz calcium sulfate. Start sparge. Boil 60 minutes, adding zinc with 15 minutes remaining. After boil, whirlpool hops for 15 minutes. Chill to 68° F and pitch yeast. Ferment at 68° F. Add the first dry hops and recirculate. After 2 days, add dry hop #2 and recirculate. Cold crash the next day to 33° F. Leave cold crashed for 4-6 days.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Missouri Beer Company English Dark Mild from Missouri Beer Company in O'Fallon, Missouri. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This malt-focused session ale from Missouri Beer Company is dark, low gravity and really refreshing. The low ABV makes the English dark mild suited for session drinking.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
6.6 lb (2.99 kg) Maris Otter Pale Malt
0.57 lb (0.26 kg) British Brown Malt
0.57 lb (0.26 kg) British Amber Malt
0.57 lb (0.26 kg) Chocolate Rye
0.2 oz (6 g) CTZ hops, 16.4% a.a. (60 min)
Wyeast 1968 Ale yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.044
Final Gravity: 1.012
ABV: 4.20%
IBU: 15
SRM: 19
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 150° F (66° C) for 60 minutes. Boil for 60 minutes. Ferment at 65° F (18° C). This yeast strain requires extra aeration for best results.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Providence Brewing Company Battlecow Galacticose New England IPA from Providence Brewing Company in North Providence, Rhode Island. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This deceptively strong beer from Providence Brewing Company is brewed with 2-Row pale malt, Carafoam, rolled oats, milk sugar, and intensely double dry-hopped with Citra and Mosaic giving it a decidedly dank aroma. Bursting with mango, orange and pineapple flavors, this is a juicy milkshake New England IPA that’ll have you begging for another sip.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
10 lb (4.5 kg) 2-row malt
2 lb (0.91 kg) Flaked Oats
1.5 lb (0.68 kg) Carafoam
1.5 lb (0.68 kg) White Wheat
2 lb (0.91 kg) Milk Sugar (lactose) (10 min)
2 oz (56 g) Columbus whole leaf hops, 14% a.a. (FWH)
2 oz (56 g) Columbus pellet hops, 14% a.a. (60 min)
2 oz (56 g) Citra pellet hops, 12% a.a. (whirlpool, 30 min)
2 oz mosaic pellet hops, 12.25% a.a. (whirlpool, 30 min)
The Yeast Bay’s Hazy Daze IPA Blend yeast
1 oz (28 g) Citra pellet hops, 12% a.a. (dry hop, 2 days into fermentation)
1 oz (28 g) Mosaic pellet hops, 12.25% a.a. (dry hop, 2 days into fermentation)
1 oz (28 g) Citra pellet hops, 12% a.a. (dry hop, 4 days)
1 oz (28 g) Mosaic pellet hops, 12.25% a.a. (dry hop, 4 days)
2 oz (56 g) Citra pellet hops, 12% a.a. (dry hop, 10 days)
2 oz (56 g) Mosaic pellet hops, 12.25% a.a. (dry hop, 10 days)
1 oz (28 g) Citra cryo hops, 26% a.a. (during kegging)
1 oz (28 g) Mosaic cryo hops, 26% a.a. (during kegging)
Specifications:
Yield: 5.5 gal (20.8 L)
Original Gravity: 1.071
Final Gravity: 1.019
ABV: 8.10%
IBU: 70
SRM: 3.6
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 155° F (68° C) for 60 minutes. Add first wort hops (FWH) as wort is being collected in the boil pot. Boil for 60 minutes, following ingredient additions as listed. Turn off heat and let temperature drop to 198° F (92° C), then add the whirlpool hops and whirlpool for 30 minutes. Chill to 70° F (21° C), transfer to a fermenter, and pitch yeast. 2 days after pitching the yeast, add the first dry hop additions (1 oz Citra; 1 oz Mosaic). After active fermentation has stopped, typically 4-5 days after pitching the yeast, add the second round of dry hops (1 oz Citra; 1 oz Mosaic). A day later, burp your fermenter (if possible) with a 30 second burst of CO2 to rouse the hops. Add 2 oz Citra and 2 oz Mosaic pellet hops 8-10 days later. Just before kegging your beer, bag and add last dry hop additions (1 oz Citra cryo; 1 oz Mosaic cryo) to the keg or bottling bucket. Enjoy!

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of River Horse Brewing Company Tripel Horse from River Horse Brewing Company in Ewing, New Jersey. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Tripel Horse has been the flagship beer of River Horse Brewing Co. since the company was founded in 1996. This dark-gold Belgian tripel has hints of clove, coriander and banana all packed into a 10% ABV beer.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
13.5 lb (6.12 kg) Pilsen Malt (Cargill IdaPils)
1.125 lb (0.51 kg) White Wheat (Briess)
0.375 lb (0.17 kg) Crystal L15 (Great Western)
2 lb (0.91 kg) Dextrose (Corn Sugar)
0.4 oz (11 g) Chinook hops, 11.8% a.a. (45 min)
0.4 oz (11 g) Hersbrucker (Hallertau) hops, 2.0% a.a. (45 min)
Whirlfloc (15 min)
Yeast Nutrient (15 min)
1 oz (28 g) Saaz hops, 4.0% a.a. (5 min)
0.2 oz (6 g) Coriander, crushed (5 min)
Belgian Trappist Yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.087 (21 P)
Final Gravity: 1.011 (2.8 P)
ABV: 10%
IBU: 18
SRM: 5
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 148° F (64° C). Sparge at 165° F (74° C). Add dextrose as you bring wort to a boil. Conduct a 60 minute boil following schedule listed in the ingredients section (it is recommended to add the coriander in a muslin bag so it can be removed). After boil, whirlpool for 5 minutes and then let the kettle sit for 15 minutes. Chill to 72° F (22° C) and pitch yeast. Aerate. Ferment at 72° F (22° C) for 7-10 days, then cold condition for 7 days. Carbonate and enjoy!

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Lupulin Brewing Straight Hash Homie IPA from Lupulin Brewing in Big Lake, Minnesota. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This appropriately named IPA from Lupulin Brewing is made with pure lupulin powder, paying homage to the brewery's name. The bursting tropical flavors and soft bitterness may fool you, but no pellet or hop touched this beer. Brew your own and see what you think!
ingredients:
Ingredients:
10.5 (4.76 kg) lbs 2-row malt
1 lb (0.45 kg) Caramalt
1 lb (0.45 kg) Flaked Rye
1 lb (0.45 kg) Vienna malt
12 oz (0.34 kg) Dextrose (60 min)
2 oz (56 g) Citra Hash (whirlpool)
2 oz (56 g) Simcoe Hash (whirlpool)
3 oz (85 g) Citra Hash (dry hop)
2 oz (56 g)Mosaic Hash (dry hop)
Omega OYL-052 yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 6 gal (22.7 L)
Original Gravity: 1.076
Final Gravity: 1.018
ABV: 7.75%
IBU: 60
SRM: 5.5
directions:
Directions:
Mash in at 152° F (67° C). Boil 6o minutes. Start fermentation at 66° F (19° C) and let rise over a week to 72° F (22° C). Dry hop once fermentation is complete. Hold on dry hops for 3 days, then crash/rack for packaging.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Church Brew Works Pious Monk Dunkel from Church Brew Works in Pittsburg, Pennsylvania. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This dark-style lager from the Church Brew Works won a Great American Beer Festival 2012 silver medal and is based on a 150-year-old recipe from Munich, Germany. This version is slightly darker and surprisingly easy drinking with a low ABV and crisp finish.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
4.16 lb (1.89 kg) Pilsner malt
4.16 lb (1.89 kg) Munich malt
12 oz (0.34 kg) Melanoidin
10 oz (0.28 kg) CaraFoam
6 oz (0.17 kg)CaraAroma
3 oz (85 g) Carafa II
0.7 oz (20 g) Perle hops, 8.1% a.a. (90 min)
0.7 oz (20 g) Tettnang hops, 4.7% a.a. (20 min)
Augustiner lager yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.054
Final Gravity: 1.012
ABV: 5.50%
IBU: 26
SRM: 16.5
directions:
Directions:
Start mash at 140° F (60° C). Pull decoction and return to mash to raise temp to 154° F (68° C). Chill wort to 50° F (10° C) and pitch yeast. Allow fermentation to free rise to 52° F (11° C). After fermentation and a diacetyl rest, drop temperature by 5 degrees a day until you reach 35° F (2° C). Lager at 35° F (2° C) for 3 weeks

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Henniker Brewing Co. Rustique Saison from Henniker Brewing Co. in Henniker, New Hampshire. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This saison is a spring offering for Henniker Brewing Company and an in-house favorite. It is estery, has a light citrus notes and a dry, peppery finish.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
7.58 lb (3.44 kg) Pilsner malt
0.88 lb (0.40 kg) Malted wheat
0.26 lb (0.12 kg) Acidulated malt
0.25 oz (7 g) German Magnum, 12% a.a. (60 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Mandarina Bavaria, 8.5% a.a. (whirlpool)
0.5 oz (14 g) Hull Melon, 7% a.a. (whirlpool)
0.5 oz (14 g) Mandarina Bavaria (dry hop)
0.5 oz (14 g) Hull Melon (dry hop)
French Saison yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.054
Final Gravity: 1.004
ABV: 6.50%
IBU: 25
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 147° F (64° C) for 60 minutes. Conduct a 60 minute boil, adding ingredients as noted in the ingredients section. Whirlpool for 20 minutes. Transfer to fermenter at 70° F (21° C) and let rise to 80° F (26° C).

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Jolly Pumpkin Artisan Ales Bam Biére from Jolly Pumpkin Artisan Ales in Dexter, Michigan. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This beerecipe was taken from the book Session Beers: Brewing for Flavor and Balance by Jennifer Talley.
Jolly Pumpkin's farmhouse ale is named for it's Jack Russell, who after being struck by a car bounced back in tenacious Jack Russell fashion. It's golden, naturally cloudy, bottle conditioned and dry hopped for a perfect flavor balance.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
4 lb (1.81 kg) Pilsner malt
2 lb (0.91 kg) 2-row Pale malt
0.75 lb (0.34 kg) Wheat malt
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Flaked Barley
1 oz (28 g) Crystal 75 malt
0.25 oz (7 g) Black malt
0.5 oz Cascade hops, 5.5% a.a. (75 min)
0.75 oz (21 g) Crystal hops, 3.5% a.a. (30 min)
0.75 oz (21 g) Crystal hops, 3.5% a.a. (0 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Crystal hops, 3.5% a.a. (dry hop)
White Labs WLP 550
Wild cultures
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.037 (9.25 P)
Final Gravity: 1.004-1.006 (1.0-1.5 P)
ABV: 4.50%
IBU: 24
directions:
Directions:
Produced with a cultured abbey ale yeast, this beer also benefits from a mixed fermentation of a house wild culture, most likely including Brettanomyces and various Lactobacillus strains. Using the bottle dregs from a Bam Biére to inspire a secondary fermentation in a small oak barrel is probably the best way to recreate this beer at home. The other option is to purchase a mixed culture packet and some oak cubes or spirals and add to the secondary carboy after primary fermentation. Mash 147-149° F (64-65° C). Free rise temperature to 80° F (27° C) and above, do not control temperature during fermentation. Step down to 50-55° F (10-13° C) once fermentation is complete. Bottle condition to high carb levels. Heavy glass bottles must be used, such as a champagne bottle, to protect from explosion. The safer option is to keg the beer in a corny keg. To dispense the beer properly, higher amounts of C02 will be needed to drwa the beer out to limit excessive foaming.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Von Ebert Brewing Sabrage Brut IPA from Von Ebert Brewing in Portland, Oregon. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Sabrage /səˈbrɑːʒ/ is the technique for opening a champagne bottle with a saber, a fitting name for this beer recipe from Von Ebert Brewing. This recipe is dry and effervescent, with minimal bitterness and hop character that's dominated by grapefruit-heavy Citra and a touch of resinous Chinook. You don't need a ceremonial occasion to drink this beer!
ingredients:
Ingredients:
8 lb (3.63 kg) Pilsner malt
2 lb (0.91 kg) Flaked Rice
2 oz (56 g) Citra hops (mash)
2 oz (56 g) Citra hops (lauter)
2 oz (56 g) Citra hops (whirlpool)
6 oz (170 g) Citra hops (dry hop)
2 oz (56 g) Chinook hops (dry hop)
Specifications:
Yield: 5.5 gal (20.8 L)
Original Gravity: 1.05
Final Gravity: 1
ABV: 6.60%
IBU: 10
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 142° F (61° C) for 60 minutes. Mash out at 168° F (76° C). Lauter onto Citra hops. Boil for 90 minutes. Add cold water to hit target gravity if needed, then add whirlpool hops. Ferment with a neutral ale strain at 65° F (18° C). After terminal and diacetyl rest, dry hop for 3-5 days. Force carbonate or bottle condition to 3.0 volumes of CO2. For a special version of this recipe, try incorporating a grape varietal into the fermentation.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Boiler Brewing Co. Bobber’s Big Red Rye Pale Ale from Boiler Brewing Co. in Lincoln, Nebraska. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This beer from Boiler Brewing Company was created as a collaboration with Lincoln, Nebraska, homebrewer Bob Catherall of the world famous Lincoln Lagers Homebrew Club. The spicy rye notes blend so perfectly with the new school Mosaic hops that it's hard to tell where the rye ends and the hops begin. Boiler was lucky enough to win a Gold Medal at the U.S. Open Beer Championship with the very first batch of this beer.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
8 lb (3.63 kg) Golden Promise
2 lb (0.91 kg) (Flaked Rye
1 lb (0.45 kg) Melanoidin malt
1 lb (0.45 kg) Pale Wheat malt
8 oz (0.23 kg) Caramunich 2 malt
8 oz (0.23 kg) Special B malt
8 oz (0.23 kg) Rice Hulls
1 oz (28 g) Columbus hops, 11.4% a.a. (FWH)
1 Whirfloc Tablet (15 min)
Lallemand BRY-97 yeast
5 oz (142 g) Mosaic pellet hops, 11.8% a.a. (dry hop)
3 oz (85 g) Mosaic whole leaf hops, 8.9% a.a. (dry hop)
Specifications:
Yield: 5.5 gal (20.8 L)
Original Gravity: 1.058
Final Gravity: 1.015
ABV: 5.60%
IBU: 40
SRM: 12.5
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 155° F (68° C) for 60 minutes. Rehydrate and pitch yeast. Ferment at 66° F (19° F), then warm it up at the end for a diacetyl rest. Dry hop with the pellets for 3 days, then cold crash before kegging. The whole leaf Mosaic hops go in the keg in a mesh bag for as long as the keg lasts (it won’t last long). Tip: before racking to the keg, add the whole leaf hops, then pump up to 15 PSI with CO2, then vent, repeating several times to remove as much O2 as possible before racking.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Bissel Brothers Brewing The Substance New England IPA from Bissell Brothers Brewing in Portland, Maine. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
The Substance from Bissel Brothers Brewing Co. flirts with the new world IPA style in a way that intrigues and compels, adding complexity and not detracting from the beer. It does have notes of tropical citrus, but it is still first and foremost “dank” with a perceived bitterness that contributes to an overall balanced experience.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
10 lb (4.53 kg) Pale 2-row malt
1.18 lb (0.53 kg) Flaked Wheat
5.6 oz Crystal 20 malt
3.8 oz Flaked Oats
Apollo hops (bittering)
1 oz Falconer’s Flight hops (flameout)
1 oz Centennial hops (flameout)
3 oz Falconer’s Flight hops (dry hop)
1.5 oz Centennial hops (dry hop)
1 oz Eureka hops (dry hop)
1 oz Apollo hops (dry hop)
1 oz Chinook hops (dry hop)
California Common yeast (Wyeast 2112, WLP 810, or similar)
Specifications:
Yield: 5.16 gal (19.5 L)
Original Gravity: 1.061
Final Gravity: 1.011
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 150-152° F (65-67° C). Ferment at 68° F (20° C), rising to 70-72° F (21-22° C) in second day of fermentation.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Iron Monk Brewing Co. Velvet Antler Amber from Iron Monk Brewing Co. in Stillwater, Oklahoma. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Iron Monk Brewing's American amber ale is very malt-forward and smooth. They hear from fans all the time that this is their all-time favorite beer, and we think you'll agree once you brew some yourself.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
7.0 lb (3.18 kg) 2-row malt
2.0 lb (0.91 kg) Caramel 60L malt
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Munich Light malt
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Red malt
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Flaked Wheat
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Flaked Barley
0.4 oz (11 g) Simcoe hops (60 min)
0.3 oz (8 g) Cascade hops (0 min)
Safale S-05
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.045
ABV: 4.60%
IBU: 14
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 154° F (68° C) for 60 minutes. Mash out at about 170° F (77° C) for 10-15 min. Sparge and lauter as usual. Boil for 60 min. Pitch yeast at 68° F (20° C). Ferment at 68° F (20° C). Secondary until clear.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Fargo Brewing Company Wood Chipper IPA from Fargo Brewing Company in Fargo, North Dakota. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This classic American IPA from Fargo Brewing Company showcases aromatic and bold hop flavors. Horizon hops and oats provide a sleek, velvety body and balanced bitterness while pounds per barrel of Cascade, Centennial, Chinook and Simcoe hops give this IPA waves of citrus and pine flavors. That’s one delicious beer eh? Oh yeah, you betcha!
ingredients:
Ingredients:
10.5 lb (4.76 kg) Pale malt
1 lb (0.45 kg) Munich I malt
Rice hulls (as much needed for your system)
0.5 oz (14 g) Centennial hops, 5.8% a.a. (FWH)
0.75 oz (21 g) Horizon hops, 11.3% a.a. (60 min)
0.75 oz (21 g) Cascade hops, 7.55% a.a. (10 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Chinook hops, 11.1% a.a. (10 min)
Whirfloc (15 min)
Servomyces (10 min)
1 oz (28 g) Centennial hops, 5.8% a.a. (whirlpool)
0.5 oz (14 g) Cascade hops, 7.55% a.a. (whirlpool)
0.25 oz (7 g) Chinook hops, 11.1% a.a. (whirlpool)
American Ale yeast
1 oz (28 g) Simcoe hops (dry hop)
1 oz (28 g) Chinook hops (dry hop)
1 oz (28 g) Centennial hops (dry hop)
1 oz (28 g) Cascade hops (dry hop)
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.062
ABV: 6.50%
IBU: 59
SRM: 4.5
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 155° F (68 °C). Boil for 60 minutes, following additions as listed in the ingredients. Ferment in the temperature range called for by the yeast used.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Seventh Son Brewing Co. Oubliette Russian Imperial Stout from Seventh Son Brewing Co. in Columbus, Ohio. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This nearly opaque imperial stout from Seventh Son Brewing Co. boasts hints of plum, dark cocoa and a pleasing warm alcohol finish. Oubliette may be the french word for dark forgotten dungeon, but you are guaranteed to remember this dark stout.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
28 lb (12.7 kg) 2-row malt
5 lb (2.27 kg) Weyermann Munich 2
2 lb (0.91 kg)  Simpson's chocolate malt
1 lb (0.45 kg) Simpson's dark crystal
1 lb (0.45 kg) Simpson's light crystal
1 lb (0.45 kg) Simpson's extra dark crystal
1 lb (0.45 kg) Crisp pale chocolate malt
12 oz (0.34 kg) Briess Midnight Wheat malt
5 lb (2.27 kg) dark candy sugar
1 oz (28 g) Mosaic hops (180 min)
1 oz (28 g) Glacier hops (180 min)
2 oz (56 g) Magnum hops (60 min)
2 oz (56 g) Glacier hops (15 min)
1 oz (28 g) Mosaic hops (15 min)
2 oz (56 g) Mosaic hops (flameout)
2 oz (56 g) Glacier hops (flameout)
British ale yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 10 gal (37.8 L)
Original Gravity: 1.112
Final Gravity: 1.02
ABV: 12%
IBU: 90
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 148° F (64° C). Keep fermentation temperatures on the cooler side of the yeast strain’s temperature range. If Glacier hops aren’t available, Willamette can be substituted.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Wedge Brewing Co. Golem Belgian Strong Pale Ale from Wedge Brewing Co. in Asheville, North Carolina. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This beer from Wedge Brewing Co. was first brewed in 2000 at home in Georgia after falling in love with the Belgian beer Piraat. Named Golem after Led Zeppelin's lyric in "Ramble On," this beer has evolved over the years into a perfect balance of malt sweetness, yeast esters and Czech Saaz.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
10 lb (4.53 kg) Belgian Pilsner malt
1 lb (0.45 kg) Wheat malt
8 oz (0.23 kg) Acidulated malt (more if your water is high pH)
8 oz (0.23 kg) Flaked Oats
8 oz (0.23 kg) Flaked Corn
4-8 oz (113-227 g) Rice Hulls (depending on your system)
2 lb (0.91 kg) Belgian Rock Candy Sugar (if syrup, use 3 lb)
1 oz (28 g) Styrian Golding hops (FWH)
2 oz (56 g) Styrian Golding hops (80 min)
1 oz (28 g) Czech Saaz hops (10 min)
2 oz (56 g) Czech Saaz hops (whirlpool)
Irish Moss (15 min)
Yeast Nutrient (15 min)
Belgian yeast: WLP 570, Wyeast 3787, WLP 510 (a bit less estery), Wyeast 3522, are just a few good ones
Specifications:
Yield: 5.5 gal (20.8 L)
Original Gravity: 1.086
Final Gravity: 1.015
ABV: 9.50%
IBU: 45-50
SRM: 6.5
directions:
Directions:
Mash schedule: 131° F (55° C) for 15 minutes; 146-148° F (63-64° C) for 30 minutes; 152° F (67° C) for 40 minutes; 158-162° F (70-72° C) for 15 minutes; mash out to 168° F (76° C( for 30 minutes. Collect runnings, adding first wort hop addition to the kettle. Boil 90 minutes. Cool to 70° F (21° C) as quickly as possible and pitch yeast. If oxygen injection is possible, do it! If not, shake the hell out of the carboy or use another method for aeration. Allow primary fermentation at 66-72° F (19-22° C) for 10 days. Then slow bring temperature down 5° F per day until you reach 33-42° F (1-6° C). Condition at this temperature for 6-8 weeks. Carbonate and enjoy.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Great South Bay Brewery Massive IPA from Great South Bay Brewery in Bay Shore, New York. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Let's just say this Massive IPA from New York's Great South Bay Brewery doesn't skimp on the hops! With a hefty dose of flameout hops, Massive IPA is packed full of American hop flavor and aroma.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
10.5 lb (4.76 kg) Domestic 2-row malt
0.75 lb (0.24 kg)  Weyermann caraamber
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) crystal 30'L
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) light dextrine malt such as carapils
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Pre-gelatinized flaked oats
0.75 oz (21 g) Chinook hops (60 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Centennial hops (1 min)
1 oz (28 g) Cascade hops (1 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Simcoe hops (1 min)
0.25 oz (7 g) Cascade hops (flameout)
0.25 oz (7 g) Centennial hops (flameout)
0.5 oz (14 g) Simcoe hops (flameout)
0.5 oz (14 g) Cascade hops (dry hop)
0.5 oz (14 g) Simcoe hops (dry hop)
American Ale yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.065 (16 P)
Final Gravity: 1.011 (2.9 P)
ABV: 6.70%
IBU: 55
SRM: 10
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 151° F (suggested: 1 tsp. CaSO4). Ferment with your favorite American Ale strain at its suggested temperature. Dry hop at high krausen. Carbonate to 2.5 volumes CO2. Compare the the real thing!

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Outlaw Brewing Udder Madness Chocolate Milk Stout from Outlaw Brewing in Bozeman, Montana. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Winter can be long and cold in Montana, leaving a beer with a bit more body to be desired. Outlaw Brewing has come to love this beer for its full body, rich mouthfeel, and utter deliciousness.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
5 lb (2.27 kg) 2-row malt
10 oz (283 g) Flaked wheat
6 oz (170 g) Crystal 45
6 oz (170 g) Chocolate malt
5 oz (142 g) Flaked Oats
3.7 oz (105 g) Roasted barley
0.4 oz (11 g)  Northern Brewer hops (60 min)
5 oz (142 g) Lactose Sugar (10 min)
0.4 oz (11 g) Fuggle hops (5 min)
American ale yeast
Chocolate (see instructions)
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.058 (14.2 P)
Final Gravity: 1.014 (3.6 P)
ABV: 5.70%
IBU: 21
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 152° F (67° C) for 60 minutes. Add hops and lactose per recipe. Ferment at 68° F (20° C) until gravity drops to 1.024 (6 P), then allow to free rise to 70° F (21° C). After diacetyl rest, remove from yeast and cold crash. Add chocolate of choice (Outlaw Brewing prefers an organic cocao at a rate of 6 oz per gallon). Swirl carboy periodically for first day, then allow to settle for 4 days. Transfer off chocolate, carbonate, and enjoy!

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Dreaming Creek Brewery 1792 Kentucky Common from Dreaming Creek Brewery in Richmond, Kentucky. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
The Kentucky common was a once popular recipe that originated in the Louisville, Kentucky area. Lost to Prohibition and recently resurrected, this has once again become a popular style of beer across the Bluegrass state and beyond.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
7 lb 2-Row malt
1.5 lb Flaked Yellow Corn
0.5 lb Flaked Rye
0.25 lb Black malt (500 L)
0.25 lb Crystal 120L malt
0.5 oz (14 g) Cluster hops, 7% a.a. (60 min)
0.2 oz Cluster hops, 7% a.a. (30 min)
0.2 oz Hallertau Mittelfreuh hops, 10.5% a.a. (20 min)
Safale US-05
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.051
Final Gravity: 1.011
ABV: 5.20%
IBU: 20.2
SRM: 15.3
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 152° F. Ferment at 65° F. Carbonate to 3 volumes CO2.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Perfect Plain Brewing Co. Holy Spin American IPA from Perfect Plain Brewing Co. in Pensacola, Florida. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Dubbed the Holy Spin, the third spin of a vinyl record is known to be when the tunes are at their best. This IPA recipe from Perfect Plain Brewing Co. was the third turn of their brewhouse and is dry-hopped, abundantly so, with citra hops to the tune of 3.3lb/bbl!
ingredients:
Ingredients:
8.5 lb (3.9 kg) American Pale 2-row
2.1 lb (0.95 kg)  Unmalted White Wheat
10 oz (283 g) Flaked Oats
1 oz (28 g) Nugget hops, 12.5% a.a. (60 min)
2 oz (56 g) Citra hops (whirlpool)
2 oz (56 g) Citra hops (dry hop)
5 oz (142 g) Citra hops (dry hop)
Chico/American Ale yeast (Safale US-05)
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.061
Final Gravity: 1.01
ABV: 6.50%
IBU: 43
SRM: 5
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 150° F (66° C) targeting a mash pH between 5.2 – 5.4. Sparge as you normally would and collect your runnings. Boil for 90 minutes. Chill wort below 170° F (77° C) or below (if possible) before adding whirlpool hops for 15 minutes. Cool wort to 66° F (19° C) and pitch yeast. Dry hop with 2 oz of Citra hops 48 hours after the start of primary fermentation, being careful to prevent as much oxygen pickup as possible. Once final gravity is reached, add the remaining 5 oz of Citra dry hops for 5 days. Crash and carbonate to 2.5 volumes of CO2.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Denali Brewing Co. Mother Ale Blonde from Denali Brewing Company in Talkeetna, Alaska. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Mother Ale is the lightest of Denali Brewing's lineup of signature ales. This blonde ale is brewed with pilsner and wheat malts, hopped with American and European hops and fermented with lager yeast at warm ale temperatures. Why the name Mother Ale? Because these brewers love their mothers!
ingredients:
Ingredients:
10 lb (4.5 kg) Superior Pilsner
0.75 lb (0.34 kg)  Destra-Pils
0.75 lb (0.34 kg) Malted White Wheat
0.75 lb (0.34 kg) Vienna malt
0.4 oz (11 g) Mt. Hood hops, 4.7% a.a. (60 min)
0.65 oz (18 g) Sterling hops, 7.4% a.a. (60 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Sterling hops, 7.4% a.a. (15 min)
0.75 oz (21 g) Czech Saaz hops, 2.9% a.a. (10 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Czech Saaz hops, 2.9% a.a. (dry hop)
0.35 oz (10 g) Sterling hops, 7.4% a.a. (dry hop)
0.15 oz (4 g) Chinook hops, 12.2% a.a. (dry hop)
0.4 oz (11 g) Fermentis SafLager 34/70 yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.049
Final Gravity: 1.008
ABV: 5.40%
IBU: 35
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 148° F (64° C) for 60 minutes. Mash out at 168° F (76° C). Sparge at 172° F (78° C). Conduct a 90 minute boil. Ferment at 67° F (19° C). Add dry hops on day 7.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Nortons Brewing Co. Don’t Poke the Bear Milk Stout from Norton's Brewing Company in Wichita, Kansas. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
From Dan Norton of Nortons Brewing Company: "In the 18 years I've been professionally brewing, I've always brewed a beer in honor of each of my 3 kids. They get to name their beer, and tell me what they want it to taste like. My oldest child came up with Don't Poke the Bear, a chocolate imperial milk stout with vanilla."
ingredients:
Ingredients:
12 lb Maris Otter Pale malt
1.3 lb Rahr White Wheat malt
11.5 oz Weyermann Munich I
9.7 oz Crisp Chocolate malt
9.6 oz Flaked Oats
9.6 oz Flaked Barley
7.8 oz Crips Roasted Barley
0.4 oz Galena hops, 12.5% a.a. (60 min)
0.9 oz Mt. Hood hops, 6% a.a. (15 min)
1.5 lb Lactose (20 min)
Wyeast 1028 London Ale yeast
Yeast Nutrient (10 min)
1 oz Dutch Cocoa (30 min)
6 oz Cocoa Nibs (see instructions)
2 Vanilla Beans (see instructions)
2 oz Coffee (see instructions)
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.096
Final Gravity: 1.035
ABV: 8.20%
IBU: 17.1
SRM: 38.3
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 152° F for 60 minutes. Mash out at 168° F for 10 minutes. Sparge at 168° F for 10 minutes. Whirlpool for 10 minutes before chilling. Ferment at 68° F. Add coca nibs in a sanitized muslin bag after 75% of fermentation is complete. A diacetyl rest is recommended. Add cold brew, made from your favorite coffee, to secondary and rack on top. Add vannila tincture (started on brew day) to secondary for 1 week.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Crooked Hammock Brewery Haulin’ Oats Milk Stout from Crooked Hammock Brewery in Lewes, Delaware. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This dark roasted sweet stout from Crooked Hammock Brewery is heavy in body and color but light in its mouthfeel thanks to rolled oats and lactose, providing an underlying sweetness that is sure to make your dreams come true.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
16.5 lb (7.48 kg) 2-row malt
3.5 lb (1.59 kg) Flaked Oats
3 lb (1.36 kg) Munich malt
1 lb (0.45 kg) Crystal 60
1 lb (0.45 kg) Chocolate wheat
1 lb (0.45 kg) Roasted barley
1 lb (0.45 kg) Perla Negra
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Carafa III
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Black malt
0.03 oz (1 g) Fermcap (60 min)
0.77 oz (22 g) CTZ hops (60 min)
0.42 oz (12 g) Fuggle hops (30 min)
0.07 oz (2 g) Whirfloc (15 min)
0.14 oz (4 g) Yeastex (15 min)
3 lb (1.36 kg) Lactose (15 min)
White Labs WLP001
Specifications:
Yield: 15 gal (56.8 L)
Original Gravity: 1.068 (16.5 P)
ABV: 5.80%
IBU: 18
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 151° F (61° C) until conversion is complete. Conduct a 60 minute boil. Ferment at 65° F (18° C) until fermentation is complete, and then cold crash prior to packaging. Note: The target original gravity of 1.068 (16.5 P) is projected after the lactose addition.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Triton Brewing Co. Fieldhouse Wheat from Triton Brewing Company & Bistro in Indianapolis, Indiana. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This American wheat ale from Triton Brewing Company is a 2017 Great American Beer Festival bronze medal winner from Indiana. The golden color, white head and crisp flavor will satisfy any wheat lover's cravings!
ingredients:
Ingredients:
15.5 lb (7.03) 2-row malt
5 lb (2.27) White Wheat;
8 oz (0.23 kg) Flaked Barley
0.9 oz (25 g) Goldings hops, 4.8% a.a. (50 min)
0.6 oz (17 g) Liberty hops, 4.5% a.a. (50 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Falconers hops, 11.3% a.a. (20 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Falconers hops (5 min)
0.9 oz (14 g) Falconers hops (dry hop - 6 days)
Safale US-05 yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 10 gal (37.8 L)
Original Gravity: 1.055 (13.5 P)
Final Gravity: 1.028 (7 P)
ABV: 5%
IBU: 25
SRM: 4.1
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 154° F (68° C). We usually boil 90 minutes, but homebrewers should be fine with 60 minutes. Ferment at 68° F (20° C).

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Two Roads Brewing Co. Worker’s Comp Farmhouse Ale from Two Roads Brewing Company in Stratford, Connecticut. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This beer is named for the concept of compensating migrant farm workers of yore with beer as part of their pay. Imagining these farms beers were brewed with a variety of surplus grains, Two Roads Brewing crafted this saison with a blend of barley, wheat, oats, rye and spelt for a subtle complexity.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
5.7 lb (2.58 kg) Pilsner malt
5.0 oz (142 g) Munich malt
10.5 oz (298 g) Wheat malt
6.5 oz (184 g) Rye malt
6.0 oz  (170 g) Spelt malt
2.5 oz (71 g) Oat malt
3.5 oz (99 g) Flaked Oats
5.0 oz (142 g) Acidulated malt
0.75 oz (14 g) Hallertauer Tradition hops, 6.5% a.a. (60 min)
0.50 oz (14 g) Kent Goldings hops, 5.2% a.a. (10 min)
0.50 oz (14 g) Crystal hops, 6.2% a.a. (10 min)
White Labs 3711 or BSI S-26 yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.043 (10.7 P)
Final Gravity: 1.007 (1.8 P)
ABV: 4.80%
IBU: 21
SRM: 3
directions:
Directions:
Mash at 65° C (149° F) for 45 minutes. Boil for 60 minutes. Cool wort to 18° C (66° F). Pitch yeast and allow to free rise to 25.5° C (78° F).

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Corridor Brewery Wizard Fight American IPA from Corridor Brewery & Provisions in Chicago, Illinois. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This flagship beer from Corridor Brewery features a plethora of cool kid hops including Mosaic, Citra, and El Dorado create a citrus and tropical paradise.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
8 lb (3.63 kg) 2-row malt
12 oz (0.34 kg) Bonlander Munich malt
12 oz (0.34 kg) Cara Pils
4 oz (113 g) Flaked Oats
0.75 oz (21 g) Warrior hops, 16% a.a. (90 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Chinook hops, 13% a.a. (15 min)
0.64 oz (18 g) Citra hops, 13% a.a. (0 min)
0.64 oz (18 g) El Dorado hops, 15% a.a. (0 min)
0.64 oz (18 g) Mosaic hops, 11% a.a. (0 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Mosaic hops (dry hop)
0.5 oz (14 g) Citra hops (dry hop)
0.5 oz (14 g) El Dorado hops (dry hop)
Brewing Science Institute London III (Ale)
.
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.059 (14.5 P)
Final Gravity: 1.010 (2.5 P)
ABV: 6.50%
IBU: 60
directions:
Directions:
Mash grains at 152° F (67° C) for 1 hour. Addition of 0.5 g CaSO4 and 0.5 g CaCl2 at mash in. 90 minute boil. Ferment at 68° F (20° C). Dry hop for five days. Cold crash one day after dry hopping.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Odell Brewing Company 90 Shilling Ale from Odell Brewing Company in Fort Collins, Colorado. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
90 Shilling is Odell Brewing Co.'s smooth and complex flagship beer, a medium-bodied amber ale with a distinct burnished copper color. Only the highest quality beers were taxed 90 shillings in the old Scottish taxing system -- you’ll find this ale brilliantly refreshing and worth every shilling.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
7.2 lb (3.3 kg) Pale malt
1 lb (0.45 kg) Munich malt
0.75 lb (0.34 kg) Crystal 10 malt
0.5 lb (0.23 kg) Flake Wheat
4.8 oz (136 g) Crystal 15 malt
1.6 oz (45 g) Chocolate malt
0.2 oz (6 g) Cascade hops, 5.5% (90 min)
0.2 oz (6 g) Perle hops, 8% a.a. (90 min)
0.1 oz (3 g) Nugget hops, 13% a.a. (90 min)
0.2 oz (6 g) Perle hops, 8% a.a. (45 min)
0.1 oz (3 g) Cascade hops, 5.5% a.a. (45 min)
0.1 oz (3 g) Nugget hops, 13% a.a. (45 min)
0.2 oz (6 g) Perle hops , 8% a.a. (0 min)
0.1 oz (3 g) Cascade hops, 5.5% a.a. (0 min)
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.048 (12 P)
Final Gravity: 1.008 (2.1 P)
ABV: 5.30%
IBU: 27
SRM: 8.5
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 153° F (67° C). Add salts (0.33g MgSO4; 6g CaSO4; 0.2g NaCl). Perform a 90 minute boil. Ferment at 67° F (19° C). Two days after gravity has stabilized and a diacetyl test has been conducted, let chill for 2 weeks before packaging.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Boise Brewing Dark Daisy Chocolate Milk Stout from Boise Brewing Company in Boise, Idaho. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This 6% milk stout is brewed with lactose which imparts a creamy, sweet character to this overall roast-y and dark chocolate-y brew. Boise Brewing uses two different types of chocolate malt plus a touch or roast to get the dark chocolate character.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
10.1 lb Pale malt
1.1 lb Chocolate malt (630 L)
11.2 oz Carafa Special II
11.2 oz Wheat malt
8 oz Brown malt
6.4 oz Lactose
0.6 oz Centennial hops, 10% a.a. (60 min)
0.75 oz Centennial hops, 10% a.a. (30 min)
Ale yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.07
Final Gravity: 1.02
ABV: 7.10%
IBU: 40
SRM: 63
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 154° F (68° C).

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Ladyface Ale Companie La Grisette from Ladyface Ale Companie in Agoura Hills, California. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Ladyface Ale Companie brews their award-winning Belgian, French and American ales in the Agoura Hills of California. La Grisette is a thirst-quenching Belgian farmhouse ale akin to saison, which took silver in the 2018 Las Angeles International Beer Competition.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
3.8 lb (1.72 kg) Pale 2-row malt
3.8 lb (1.72 kg) Pale Wheat malt
1.25 lb (0.57 kg) Acidulated malt
1.12 lb (0.51 kg) Flaked Oats
0.1 oz (2.8 g) Apollo hops, 18.5% a.a. (60 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Apollo hops, 18.5% a.a. (20 min)
Brewing Science Institute B-22 La Chouffe Belgian yeast or your favorite Belgian yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.051
ABV: ~5%
IBU: 28
SRM: 4
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 150° F (66 °C). Ferment in the temperature range called for by the yeast strain used.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Denizens Brewing Co. Lowest Lord ESB from Denizens Brewing Co. in Silver Spring, Maryland. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This extra special bitter is a more hop-forward version of the English bitter from Denizens Brewing Co. With classic ESB notes of toffee and biscuit, they use a mix of English and American hops to create a floral and herbal balance with the malt.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
5 lb (2.27 kg) 2-row malt
2.75 lb (1.25 kg) Maris Otter malt
12 oz (0.34 kg) Munich I malt
12 oz (0.34 kg) Aromatic Barley malt
9 oz (0.25 kg) Crystal 45 malt
4 oz  (0.11 kg) Acidulated malt
2 oz (57 g) Pale Chocolate malt
0.5 oz (14 g) Nugget hops, 13% a.a. (45 min)
1 oz (28 g) Target hops, 10% a.a. (10 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Target hops, 10% a.a. (5 min)
1 oz (28 g) Crystal hops, 3.3% a.a. (5 min)
White Labs WLP007 Dry English Ale yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.054
Final Gravity: 1.014
ABV: 5.30%
IBU: 42
SRM: 14
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash around 152° F (67° C). Conduct a 90 minute boil, following hop additions as listed in the ingredients section. Ferment in the temperature range called for by the yeast.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Exile Brewing Company Sir Moch-A-Lot Mocha Stout from Exile Brewing Company in Des Moines, Iowa. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
“I like big stouts and I cannot lie!” Exile Brewing Co's mocha stout is brewed with Brazilian coffee beans from their neighbors up the street, Horizon Line. Roasted coffee and chocolate bitterness balance its smooth malty sweetness.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
5.8 lb (2.63 kg) Pilsner malt
2.8 lb (1.27 kg) Golden Promise
2.0 lb (0.91 kg) Flaked Oats
1.2 lb (0.54 kg) Simpson brown malt
0.9 lb (0.41 kg) Chocolate malt
0.8 lb (0.36 kg) Caramel 45
0.6 lb (0.27 kg) Black malt
1.2 oz (34 g) Cascade hops, 5.5% a.a. (60 min)
0.2 lb Cacao Nibs
Cold Brew Coffee
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.069
ABV: 7.10%
IBU: 20
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash at 154° F (68° C). Ferment at 68° F (20° C). Cold crash to 38° F (3° C) once fermentation has completed. Add cacao nibs for 5 days. Rack off of the cacao nibs and add fresh cold brew to taste. Carbonate to 2.0 volumes of CO2.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Pedal Haus Brewery Biere Blanche Belgian Witbier from Pedal Haus Brewery in Tempe, Arizona. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
A gold medal winner in the 2018 Great American Beer Festival and the 2018 Los Angeles International Beer Competition, this traditional witbier from Pedal Haus Brewery features Moroccan orange peel and coriander.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
8.25 lb (3.74 kg) Pale Wheat malt
5.4 lb (2.45 kg) Pilsner malt
2.3 lb (1.04 kg) 2-row malt
1.4 lb (0.64 kg) Flaked Wheat malt
3.5 oz (99 g) Acidulated malt
1.75 oz (50 g) German Tradition hops, 4% a.a. (90 min)
5 oz (142 g) Dried Moroccan Orange Peel (1 min)
5 oz (142 g) Freshly Ground Coriander Seed (whirlpool)
Westmalle yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 10 gal (37.8 L)
Original Gravity: 1.048
Final Gravity: 1.009
ABV: 5.10%
IBU: 14
SRM: 3.4
directions:
Directions:
Step mash: 20 minutes at 122° F (50° C); 20 minutes at 149° F (65° C); 20 minutes at 158°F (70° C). Boil for 90 minutes, following the ingredient additions as listed. After boil, whirlpool for 20 minutes before chilling. Ferment at 65° F (18° C) until fermentation is complete. Conduct a diacetyl rest for at least 5 days. Do not use kettle coagulant and do not crash too fast or the yeast will drop the protein haze with it.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Night Shift Brewing Matisse Classic Saison from Night Shift Brewing in Everett, Massachusetts. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
This classic, peppery, dry saison comes from Night Shift Brewing. A simple grist coupled with an assertive bittering hop addition help accentuate the dry characteristics and give a solid base for the phenols from the yeast. This beer took the silver medal in the Classic Saison category the 2017 Great American Beer Festival.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
9.18 lb (4.16 kg) Pilsner malt
0.7 oz (20 g) Styrian Aurora hops, 8% a.a. (FWH)
0.3 oz (8 g) Styrian Aurora hops, 8% a.a. (20 min)
0.5 (14 g) oz Saaz hops, 4% a.a. (whirlpool)
Belgian Saison yeast strain
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.048
Final Gravity: 1
ABV: 6%
IBU: 29
SRM: 3
directions:
Directions:
Single infusion mash targeting 150-152˚F (66-67˚ C), whatever gets you to complete attenuation. Add gypsum to around 250ppm sulfate. Target a 5.2 mash pH, we use lactic acid to adjust. Knockout post boil around 65˚F (18˚ C), trying to have the top end of fermentation be 70˚F (21˚ C). After five days, remove whatever temperature control you had and allow to free rise to whatever temperature it wants. Fermentation is typically about 4 weeks, we’ll drop the temperature and package in week 5. We’ve tried variations of this recipe with orange peel, peppercorns, different hops, etc. It’s a great base to play around with and experiment ideas. We’ve also tried some mixed fermenations but would recommend adding wheat or other high protein grain to give food for the other yeast/bacteria.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Honolulu BeerWorks CocoWeizen from Honolulu Beer Works in Honolulu, Hawaii. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Instead of a commonly thought of coconut dark beer, this German-style coconut hefeweizen is a lighter-bodied beer inspired by one Honolulu Beer Works brewer's wife. Honolulu BeerWorks CocoWeizen took home a gold medal at Japan's International Beer Cup 2018.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
8 lb (3.63 kg) White wheat
2.5 lb (1.13 kg) 2-row malt
1.2 oz (24 g) Crystal hops, 3.9% a.a. (60 min)
Wyeast 3068 Weihenstephan Weizen
1 lb (0.45 kg) Coconut, shredded (see instructions)
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gal (18.9 L)
Original Gravity: 1.048 (11.8 P)
Final Gravity: 1.006 (1.5 P)
ABV: 5.50%
IBU: 14
SRM: 5.5
directions:
Directions:
Conduct a mash at 150° F (66° C) for 60 minutes. Boil for 60 minutes, following the listed ingredient additions. Ferment at 72° F (22° C) for 10 days.Toast coconut until very dark, but not burnt. Add to secondary in a bag for easy removal. As you will be adding to secondary, take necessary sanitation steps when introducing the coconut. Let beer sit on coconut for 2 days. Transfer and carbonate.

description:
Try making this “clone recipe” of Ozark Beer Co. Belgian Golden Ale from Ozark Beer Company in Rogers, Arkansas. Browse our library of replica beers in the AHA Recipe Library!
Ozark Beer Co. brews this traditional Belgian-style golden ale with pilsen malt and noble hops that lend aromas of apples and pears. The perfectly timed hop additions makes it a light, dry and very refreshing homebrew.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
6.0 lbs (3.23kg) Briess Pilsner malt
2.33 lbs (1.29 kg) Briess Pale Ale malt
4.8 oz (161.6 g) Briess White Wheat
4.8 oz (161.6 g) Briess Raw White Wheat
1.9 oz (65.2 g) Weyerman Acidulated
0.6 oz (14.2 g) Sterling, 8.4% aa @ 60 min
0.6 oz (14.2 g) Sterling, 8.4% aa @ 45 min
0.6 oz (14.2 g) Sterling, 8.4% aa @ 5 min
Omega Yeast Labs OYL-500 Saisonsteins Monster or your favorite Belgian/French DRY saison strain
5.7 g Gypsum in mash
1.3 g Calcium Chloride @ 45 min in boil
1.6 g Yeast Nutrient @ 15 min in boil
1 Tab Whirlfloc @ 10 min in boil
Specifications:
