description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the July/August 2001 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
This recipe may take the better part of a year to come into its own, but the sour brown ale at the end of the rainbow is well worth the wait! Flanders Brown Ale, otherwise known as oud bruin, is likened to a malty old ale that has gone funky, with hints of fruit and sourness.
This recipe is featured in "Belgian Barm & Barrels: Making Flanders Red and Brown Ale" by Matt Stinchfield (July/August 2001 Zymurgy)
ingredients:
Ingredients:
7.5 lb (3.4 kg) Pale malt
1.5 lb (0.68 kg) Munich malt
1.0 lb (0.46 kg) CaraMunich malt
6 oz (170 g) Special B malt
4 oz (114 g) Chocolate malt
8 oz (230 g) Amber Belgian Candi Sugar
1.25 oz (35 g) Slovenian Styrian Golding hops, 4% a.a. (90 min)
0.25 oz (7 g) English Fuggles hops, 4.3% a.a. (30 minutes)
Wyeast 1388 Belgian Strong yeast (initial pitch)
Wyeast 5335 Lactobacillus (second pitch)
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gallons (19 L)
Original Gravity: 1.061
Final Gravity: 1.012
ABV: 6.40%
IBU: 28
SRM: 23
Boil Time: 120 minutes
directions:
Directions:
Primary Fermentation 68-72°F (20-22°C) for five to seven days, then pitch Wyeast 5335 into the same fermenter, increase fermentation temperature to 75-80°F (24-27°C). Leave for three weeks, then rack to secondary. Secondary Fermentation 68-72°F (20-22°C) for six months, taste for acidity prior to bottling, adjust if necessary with lactic acid or by blending with a non-acidified batch.

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the May/June 2012 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
In 2012, Dennis Decker earned best of show in the Boneyard Brew Off, a competition organized by the Boneyard Union and Zymurgical Zealots (BUZZ) homebrew club, for his Oktoberfest beer.
This recipe and the full story behind Decker's win were highlighted in the May/June 2012 issue of Zymurgy magazine.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
12.0 lb (5.44 kg) Munich malt
11.0 lb (4.99 kg) German Pilsner malt
8.0 oz (227 g) Caramel Munich malt
4.0 oz (113 g) Aromatic malt
4.0 oz (113 g) Biscuit malt
1.5 oz (42 g) Tettnanger hops, 4.5% a.a. (60 min)
1.25 oz (35 g) Hallertauer Mittelfruh hops, 4.4% a.a. (60 min)
1 tsp Calcium Chloride (in mash)
1 tsp Lactic acid (in mash)
1 tsp Irish Moss (10 min)
Starter Wyeast 2206 Bavarian Lager yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 10 gallons (37.85 L)
Original Gravity: 1.059
Final Gravity: 1.015
ABV: 5.74%
IBU: 20.3
SRM: 10.4
Boil Time: 60 minutes
Efficiency: 70%
directions:
Directions:
Use a two-step mash with a protein rest at 122°F (50°C) for 25 minutes, followed by a main rest at 152°F (67°C) for 90 minutes. Pitch yeast at 62°F (17°C), hold at that temperature for 24 hours, then drop to 50°F (10°C) and hold for 20 days. When fermentation is complete, raise temperature to 65°F (18°C) for a two-day diacetyl rest, then drop to lagering temperatures for one month or more. Carbonate to 2.4 volumes of CO2.
addition:
Extract Version:
Substitute 7.9 lb (3.6 kg) liquid Munich malt extract for the Munich malt and .7 lb (22.5 kg) liquid Pilsner malt extract for the Pilsner malt. Steep the remaining grains in 158°F (70°C) water for 30 minutes, strain, add the malt extract, bring to a boil, and proceed with the the recipe as written.

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the July/August 2003 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
In the late 19th century, Anchor Brewing Company began brewing their still-famous “steam beer.” Utilizing local ingredients and forgoing the lagering techniques that were popular during the time, Anchor Steam was highly affordable compared to other commercial lagers, which made it a favorite among the working class in San Francisco during the Gold Rush.
While other commercial and homebrewers make their own version of the uniquely-American style now known as California common, Anchor helped pioneer this style.
This recipe was originally featured in the July/August 2003 issue of Zymurgy and created by Marc Sedam.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
9.0 lb (4.1 kg) German Pils malt
1.0 lb (0.45 kg) 40°L Crystal malt
0.5 lb (227 g) Special Roast
1.0 oz (28 g) Northern Brewer hops, 7.4% a.a. (first wort)
0.75 oz (21 g) Northern Brewer hops, 7.4% a.a. (20 min)
1.0 oz (28 g) Northern Brewer hops, 7.4% a.a. (knockout)
1 Whirfloc tablet or 1 tsp (5 ml) Irish moss (20 min)
White Labs WLP810 San Francisco or Wyeast 2112 California lager yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gallons (19 L)
Original Gravity: 1.05
Final Gravity: 1.014
ABV: 4.70%
IBU: ~35
SRM: 9
Boil Time: 60 minutes
Efficiency: 70%
directions:
Directions:
Note: This recipe is intended to yield 5.5 gallons at the end of the boil, with 5 gallons racked into primary. Mash grains at 148°F (64°C) for 60 minutes. Sparge at 175°F (79°C) to collect 6.5 gallons (24.6 L) of wort before the boil. At the end of the boil, chill to 60°F (16°C), aerate and pitch. Ferment at 60°F (16°C) for 7-10 days, then transfer to secondary. When fully attenuated, package, condition and enjoy!
addition:
Extract Option
Substitute 5.5 lb (2.5 kg) light dry malt extract or 7 lb (3.18 kg) pale liquid malt extract for pils malt.
Put crushed specialty malts in a grain bag and then place into a pot with cold water. Heat pot, stirring every few minutes.
Just as the pot  begins to simmer, remove the grain bag and let drain into the pot. Add the malt extract and stir until dissolved.
Follow the directions above for boil and post-boil instructions.

description:
Mash grains at 152°F (67° C) for 60 minutes. Mash out at 170°F (77°C) for 30 minutes.
Add 1/8 lb of honey and 1 5/8 lbs table sugar to the boil at 30 minutes from flameout. Add the remaining 1/8 lb honey and 1/8 lb table sugar at 5 minutes from flameout.
Ferment one week at 70°F (21°C) in primary, followed by two weeks at 64°F (18°C) in secondary.
Use fresh, pink grapefruit, membranes removed, and add to primary at 60 hours along with the 4 ounces of light brown sugar.
Carbonate to 2.15 volumes of CO2.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
11.75 lb (5.33 kg) | Dingemans Pils malt
0.13 lb (59 g) | Dingemans biscuit malt (Mout Roost 50)
0.13 lb (59 g) | Aromatic malt (Amber 50)
1.75 lb (794 g) white table sugar (boil)
4.0 oz (113 g) | Honey (boil)
4.0 oz (113 g) | Light brown sugar (in primary)
1.0 lb (0.45 kg) | Fresh pink grapefruit (in primary)
1.5 oz (42 g) | Tettnanger pellets, 4.5% a.a. (60 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) | Tettnanger pellets, 4.5% a.a. (15 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) | Czech Saaz pellets 3% a.a. (15 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) | Czech Saaz pellets 3% a.a. (1 min)
White Labs WLP500 Trappist Ale
2 Tbsp | Irish moss, 15 minutes
Specifications:
Yield: 5 gallons (18.93 L)
Original Gravity: 1.079
Final Gravity: 1.01
ABV: 9.20%
IBU: 26
SRM: 6.8
Boil Time: 90 minutes
directions:
Directions:
Joe Nielsen of Berkley, Mich. earned a gold medal for his tripel, rising above 421 other Category 18: Belgian Strong Ale entries in the 2013 National Homebrew Competition.
Joe’s tripel uses three sugar adjunct additions: table sugar, honey and light brown sugar to increase the alcohol content, while creating that signature dry but full finish. The noble hop additions bring the bitterness on the lower end of tripel’s IBU threshold, and blends nicely with the pound of grapefruit added to the primary.

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the September/October 2014 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
Ritchie Marvin of Portland, OR won a gold medal in Category #1: Light Lager during the 2014 National Homebrew Competition Final Round in Grand Rapids, MI. Marvin’s Light Lager was chosen as the best among 179 final round entries in the category.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
5.0 lb (2.27 kg) German Pilsner malt
1.5 lb (0.68 kg) German Vienna malt
1.5 lb (0.68 kg) American two-row pale malt
0.5 lb (227 g) flaked what
0.75 oz (21 g) whole Saaz, 4.2% a.a. (60 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) whole Saaz, 4.2% a.a. (20 min)
0.75 oz (21 g) whole Ultra, 5% a.a. (10 min)
0.25 oz (7 g) whole Ultra, 5% a.a. (5 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) whole Saaz, 4.2% a.a (5 min)
WLP815 Belgian lager (1 qt starter)
1 tsp Wyeast yeast nutrient
Specifications:
Yield: 4 Gallons (15.14 L)
Original Gravity: 1.053
Final Gravity: 1.014
ABV: 5.12%
directions:
Directions:
Treat water with 1 g baking soda, 5 g calcium chloride, 4 g Epsom salts, 4 g gypsum and 4 g calcium carbonate. Single infusion mash at 149° F (65° C) for 90 minutes. Ferment 10 days at 53° F (12° C), then lager for 38 days at 35° F (2° C).
Forced CO2 to carbonate (2.5 vol).

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the September/October 2014 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
Daniel Reinholdt of Oak Park, IL, member of the Homebrewers Pride of the Southside, won a gold medal in Category #2: Pilsner during the 2014 National Homebrew Competition Final Round in Grand Rapids, MI. Reinholdt’s Pilsner was chosen as the best among 182 final round entries in the category.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
9.5 lb (4.31 kg) German Pilsner malt
9.5 lb (4.31 kg) pale two-row malt
7.0 lb (3.18 kg) flaked corn
6.0 oz (170 g) acid malt
1.0 oz (28 g) Hallertau Mittelfruh, 4% a.a. (60 min)
1.0 oz (28 g) Northern Brewer, 9.6% a.a. (20 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Northern Brewer, 9.6% a.a. (20 min)
3.5 oz (99 g) Hallertau Mittelfruh, 4% a.a. (10 min)
1.63 oz (46 g) Czech Saaz, 3.2% a.a. (5 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Northern Brewer, 9.6% a.a. (5 min)
2.0 oz (56 g) Hallertau Mittelfruh, 4% a.a. (0 min)
Wyeast 2007 Pilsen Lager yeast (starter)
1 tsp Wyeast yeast nutrient (10 min)
Specifications:
Yield: 6 Gallons (22.71 L)
Original Gravity: 1.061
Final Gravity: 1.01
ABV: 6.69%
directions:
Directions:
Use half RO water. Mash grains at 150° F (66° C) for 90 minutes.
Primary fermentation for 28 days at 50° F (10° C)

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the September/October 2014 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
Nick Rodammer of Grand Rapids, MI, member of the Brewsquitos Homebrewing Club, won a gold medal in Category #3: European Amber Lager during the 2014 National Homebrew Competition Final Round in Grand Rapids, MI. Rodammer’s European Amber Lager was chosen as the best among 161 final round entries in the category
ingredients:
Ingredients:
10.0 lb (4.54 kg) Weyermann® Vienna malt
3.5 lb (1.59 kg) Weyermann® Munich II malt
0.3 lb (136 g) Weyermann ® acid malt
1.0 oz (28 g) Hallertau Perle pellets, 7.8% a.a. (60 min)
WLP833 German Bock lager yeast (4 L starter)
1/2 tablet Whirlfloc (2 min)
1 tsp Wyeast yeast nutrient (10 min)
1 tsp gelatin finings in secondary
Specifications:
Yield: 5.5 Gallons (20.82 L)
Original Gravity: 1.056
Final Gravity: 1.012
ABV: 5.78%
directions:
Directions:
Water was 75% RO, 25% Plainfield Twp. tap water. Used a modified Hochkurz decoction mash. Rest 60 minutes at 146° F (63° C), pulled 10 quarts thick decoction, added to bowl inside of pressure cooker, heated to 15 psi for 20 minutes, let cool naturally ,added back to main mash to rest at 155° F (68° C) for 30 minutes. Mashed and sparked with 3 g calcium chloride and 1 g gypsum; sparge water acidified with 2 mL lactic acid.
Primary fermentation for 10 days at 48° F (9° C).
Secondary fermentation 7 days at 58° F (14° C).
Tertiary fermentation for 60 days at 30° F (-1° C).
Forced CO2 to carbonate (2.5 vol).

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the September/October 2014 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
Michael Wilcox of Wichita, KS, member of the Wichita Homebrewers Organization (WHO), won a gold medal in Category #4: Dark Lager during the 2014 National Homebrew Competition Final Round in Grand Rapids, MI. Wilcox’s Dark Lager was chosen as the best among 166 final round entries in the category.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
4.5 lb (2.04 kg) 20° L Munich malt (60%)
1.5 lb (0.68 kg) Pilsner malt (20%)
1.44 lb (0.65 kg) 10° L Munich malt (19%)
1.0 oz (28 g) pale chocolate malt (1%)
1.1 oz (31 g) Liberty pellets, 5% a.a. (60 min)
WLP833 German Bock lager yeast (starter)
Specifications:
Yield: 3.5 Gallons (13.25 L)
Original Gravity: 1.055
Final Gravity: 1.012
ABV: 5.64%
IBU: 25
SRM: 16
directions:
Directions:
Use half RO water and half tap water. Treatw ith 0.5 tsp calcium chloride prior to mash and adjust sparge water pH with phosphoric acid. “I use a Hockhurz-style double decoction for this one and adjust color if necessary near end of boil with pre-steeped debittered black, or Sinimar®.” Mash schedule include a protein rest at 130° F (54° C) for 20 minutes, a maltose rest at 143° F (62° C) for 60 minutes, a dextrin rest at 154° F (68° C) for 40 minutes and a mash-out at 168° F (76° C) for 20 minutes. “Aim for 25ish IBUs. Raise to 60° F (16° C) when it slows, hold for a few days before lowering. Rack to keg and lager about 6 weeks.”
Primary fermentation for 14 days at 48° F (9° C).
Forced CO2 to carbonate (2.4 vol).

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the September/October 2014 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
Kyle Schmitt of Clarkston, WA, member of the Homebrewers Of The Palouse, won a gold medal in Category #5: Bock during the 2014 National Homebrew Competition Final Round in Grand Rapids, MI with the help of Robert Hand, Mark Davis, Lee Henry & Randy Johnson. Schmitt’s Bock was chosen as the best among 232 final round entries in the category.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
50.0 lb (22.67 kg) Munich malt
15.5 lb (7.03 kg) Pilsner malt
5.8 lb (2.63 kg) Caramunich® I malt
1.6 oz (45 g) Bravo pellets, 14.2% a.a. (60 min)
3.0 oz (85 g) Hallertau pellets, 4.2% a.a. (30 min)
WLP833 German Bock lager yeast (6 L starter)
Wyeast yeast nutrient
Whirlfloc
Specifications:
Yield: 20 Gallons (75.71 L)
Original Gravity: 1.077
Final Gravity: 1.018
ABV: 7.74%
directions:
Directions:
Perform a single infusion mash at 154° F (68° C) for 60 minutes.
Primary fermentation for 30 days at 50° F (10° C).

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the September/October 2014 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
Cassidy Shibiya of Harrison, OH won a gold medal in Category #6: Light Hybrid Beer during the 2014 National Homebrew Competition Final Round in Grand Rapids, MI. Shibiya’s Light Hybrid Beer was chosen as the best among 379 final round entries in the category.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
18.0 lb (8.16 kg) Pilsner malt
1.0 lb (0.45 kg) Vienna malt
3.0 oz (85 g) Hallertau hops (60 min)
Kölsch yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 10 Gallons (37.85 L)
Original Gravity: 1.051
Final Gravity: 1.01
ABV: 5.20%

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the September/October 2014 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
Patrick Barry of Cambridge, MA won a gold medal in Category #7: Amber Hybrid Beer during the 2014 National Homebrew Competition Final Round in Grand Rapids, MI. Barry’s Amber Hybrid Beer was chosen as the best among 164 final round entries in the category.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
8.0 lb (3.63 kg) German Pilsner malt
2.0 lb (0.9 kg) Munich malt
1.0 lb (0.45 kg) aromatic malt
8.0 oz (227 g) Cara-Munich® II malt
4.0 oz (113 g) Carafa® malt
0.84 oz (24 g) Herkules pellets, 15.7% a.a. (60 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Hallertau pellets, 7.9% a.a. (15 min)
Wyeast 1007 German Ale yeast, starter
2 tsp yeast nutrient (1 in starter, 1 in boil)
Specifications:
Yield: 5.25 Gallons (19.87 L)
Original Gravity: 1.052
Final Gravity: 1.011
ABV: 5.38%
directions:
Directions:
Use brewing water with 63 ppm calcium, 0 ppm magnesium, 15 ppm sodium, 77 ppm sulfate, 64 ppm chloride, 7 ppm bicarbonate, a residual alkalinity of -39 and a hardness of 159. Mash pH at room temp should be at 5.44. Add half of Campden tablet before dough-in. Mash grains at 150° F (66° C) for 90 minutes. Mash out at 165° F (74° C) for 10 minutes. Fine fermented beer with 1 tsp gelatin.
Primary fermentation for 21 days at 61° F (16° C).
Secondary fermentation for 50 days at 35° F (2° C).
Forced CO2 to carbonate (2.6 vol).

0.6 lb (272 g) chocolate malt

0.3 oz (9 g) whole Cascade, 7.3% a.a. (30 min)
1.0 oz (28 g) Willamette pellets, 5.3% a.a. (15 min)
1.0 oz (28 g) whole Cascade, 7.3% a.a. (15 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Willamette pellets, 5.3% a.a. (5 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) whole Cascade, 7.3% a.a. (5 min)
0.3 oz (9 g) Willamette pellets, 5.3% a.a. (1 min)
0.3 oz (9 g) whole Cascade, 7.3% a.a. (1 min)

Primary fermentation for 7 days at 68° F (20° C).
Secondary fermentation for 14 days at 65° F (18° C).

description:

Rawks’s English Brown Ale was chosen as the best among 235 final round entries in the category.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
16.0 lb (7.26 kg) Maris Otter pale ale malt
1.0 lb (0.45 kg) 60° L caramel malt

8.0 oz (227 g) dextrin malt
8.0 oz (227 g) 200° L chocolate malt
4.0 oz (113 g) 300° L roast barley
2.1 oz (60 g) 500° L black malt

directions:
Directions:
“Water is carbon filtered and treated with 5.2 pH stabilizer and a bit of Campden to protect against seasonal chloramine in the municipal water supply.” Mash in at 154° F (68° C) and hold for 45 minutes. Mash out at 168° F (76° C) for 10 minutes. Sparge at 168° F (76° C).
Primary fermentation for 4 days at 68° F (20° C).
Secondary fermentation for 1 week at 72° F (22° C).
Forced CO2 to carbonate (1.5 vol).

description:

0.75 lb (340 g) pale chocolate malt

description:

Kelsey McNair of San Diego, CA, member of the QUAFF (Quality Ale and Fermentation Fraternity), won a gold medal in Category #14: India Pale Ale (IPA) during the 2014 National Homebrew Competition Final Round in Grand Rapids, MI. McNair’s India Pale Ale (IPA) was chosen as the best among 852 final round entries in the category.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
31.25 lb (14.17 kg) Great Western two-row malt
21.0 oz (595 g) Briess dextrin malt
8.0 oz (227 g) Crisp 45° L crystal malt
1.0 oz (28 g) Chinook pellets, 11.5% a.a. (FWH)
2.5 oz (70 g) Warrior pellets, 16.7% a.a. (60 min)
2.0 oz (57 g) CTZ pellets, 13.1% a.a. (30 min)
2.0 oz (57 g) Simcoe pellets, 9.3% a.a. (10 min)
2.0 oz (57 g) Amarillo pellets, 12.2% a.a. (10 min)
2.0 oz (57 g) Simcoe pellets, 9.3% a.a. (0 min)
2.0 oz (57 g) Amarillo pellets, 12.2% a.a. (0 min)
2.0 oz (57 g) Citra pellet pellets, 13.4% a.a. (0 min)
2.0 oz (57 g) Centennial pellets, 8.8% a.a. (0 min)
2.0 oz (57 g) CTZ pellet pellets, 17.6% a.a. (0 min)
1.0.0 oz (28 g) Simcoe pellets, 9.3% a.a. (hop back)
1.0 oz (28 g) Amarillo pellets, 12.2% a.a. (hop back)
1.0 oz (28 g) Citra pellets, 13.4% a.a. (hop back)
2.0 oz (57 g) Simcoe pellets, 9.3% a.a. (dry)
2.0 oz (57 g) Amarillo pellets, 12.2% a.a. (dry)
2.0 oz (57 g) Citra pellet pellets, 13.4% a.a. (dry)
2.0 oz (57 g) Centennial pellets, 8.8% a.a. (dry)
2.0 oz (57 g) CTZ pellets, 17.6% a.a. (dry)
WLP001 California Ale yeast
3 Whirlfloc tablets (15 min)
2 Servomyces yeast nutrient tablets (15 min)
0.25 tsp Super Moss HB (10 min) to clarify
1 tsp Wyeast nutrient (10 min)
Specifications:
Yield: 14 Gallons (53 L)
Original Gravity: 1.067
Final Gravity: 1.011
ABV: 7.35%
IBU: 120
SRM: 5
directions:
Directions:
Mash in at 152° F (67° C) and rest for 60 minutes. Mash out at 168° F (76° C) and hold for 15 minutes. Sparge at 170° F (77° C) for 60 minutes. Chill to 67° F (19° C) and pitch. After primary fermentation, rack and add 50 percent of dry hops and dry hop for 3 days, then add remaining dry hops and dry hop for 4 additional days.
Primary Fermentation for 7-10 days at 67° F (19° C).
Secondary Fermentation for 7 days at 67° F (19° C).
Forced CO2 to carbonate (2.4 vol).

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the September/October 2014 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
Scott Hixson of Gulfport, MS, member of the Gulf Coast Brewers League, won a gold medal in Category #15: German Wheat and Rye Beer during the 2014 National Homebrew Competition Final Round in Grand Rapids, MI with the help of Theresa Hixson. Hixson’s German Wheat and Rye Beer was chosen as the best among 208 final round entries in the category.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
6.9 lb (3.13 kg) white wheat malt
4.4 lb (2 kg) pale malt
0.5 lb (227 g) 10° L Munich malt
0.4 lb (181 g) pale chocolate malt
0.3 lb (136 g) Caramunich® I malt
0.3 lb (136 g) Caramunich® III malt
0.3 lb (136 g) melanoidin malt
1.0 oz (28 g) Hallertau pellets, 4% a.a. (FWH)
0.3 oz (8.5 g) Hallertau pellets, 4% a.a.. (15 min)
WLP380 Hefeweizen IV ale yeast (2 vials)
Specifications:
Yield: 5 Gallons (18.93 L)
Original Gravity: 1.072
Final Gravity: 1.018
ABV: 7.09%
directions:
Directions:
Begin with an acid rest at 111° F (44° C) and hold for 15 minutes. Ramp up to 125° F (52° C) and hold for a 15 minute protein rest. Finish with a saccharification rest at 153° F (67° C) for one hour.
Primary Fermentation for 8 days at 68-72° F (20-22° C).
Secondary Fermentation for  8 days at 65° F (18° C).
Tertiary fermentation for 175 days at 36° F (2° C).
Keg condition to 4.2 vol. CO2

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the September/October 2014 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
Morgan Sapp of Clarksville, TN, member of the Clarksville Carboys, won a gold medal in Category #16: Belgian and French Ale during the 2014 National Homebrew Competition Final Round in Grand Rapids, MI. Sapp’s Belgian and French Ale was chosen as the best among 591 final round entries in the category.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
12.5 lb (5.67 kg) Pilsner malt
6.0 oz (170 g) aromatic malt
1.25 lb (0.57 kg) wheat malt
5.0 lb (2.27 kg) Shuksan strawberries
0.75 oz (21 g) coriander
0.75 oz (21 g) bitter orange peel
0.25 oz (7 g) grains of paradise
0.5 oz (14 g) Hallertau pellets, 4.65% a.a. (90 min)
0.5 oz (14 g) Hallertau pellets, 4.65% a.a. (60 min)
1.0 oz (28 g) Styrian Goldings pellets, 5.4 % a.a. (15 min)
Wyeast 3726 Farmhouse ale yeast (2 L starter)
0.5 tsp yeast nutrient
Specifications:
Yield: 5 Gallons (18.93 L)
Original Gravity: 1.055
Final Gravity: 1
ABV: 7.22%
IBU: 19
SRM: 19
directions:
Directions:
“After primary fermentation, I pureed 5 lb (2.27 kg) of frozen Shuksan variety strawberries and brought them to 160° F (71° C). I then racked onto the puree in secondary and added dregs from an all Brett-trois fermented beer. This is the same yeast as the Brett B (trois) offered by White Labs.”
Primary Fermentation for 21 days at 74° F (23° C).
Secondary Fermentation for 60 days at 70° F (21° C).
Bottle conditioned

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the September/October 2014 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
Jim Fish of Brooklawn, NJ, member of the Barley Legal Hombrew Club, won a gold medal in Category #17: Sour Ale during the 2014 National Homebrew Competition Final Round in Grand Rapids, MI. Fish’s Sour Ale was chosen as the best among 286 final round entries in the category.
ingredients:
Ingredients:
9.75 lb (4.42 kg) Belgian Pils malt
4.0 lb (1.81 kg) Munich malt
0.75 (340 g) Caramunich® malt
0.5 lb (227 g) wheat
0.5 lb (227 g) aromatic malt
0.5 lb (227 g) Special B malt
2.0 oz (57 g) Carafa® III malt
8 14.5-oz cans Oregon tart cherries in water
1.0 oz (28 g) E.K. Golding pellets (60 min)
Wyeast 1056 American Ale yeast
Wyeast 3278 Lambic Blend ale yeast
Champagne yeast
Specifications:
Yield: 5.5 Gallons (20.82 L)
Original Gravity: 1.07
Final Gravity: 1.008
ABV: 8.14%
directions:
Directions:
Use a single infusion mash at 152° F (67° C) for 60 minutes. When primary fermentation is complete, transfer to secondary and pitch the lambic blend.Age at basement temps (62-78° F, 17-26° C). Ferment for 1 year then pitch 8 cans of Oregon sour cherries. Age for 3 more months in tertiary until clear. Bottle with champagne yeast when gravity settles around 1.008.
Primary Fermentation for 7 days at 64° F (18° C).
Secondary Fermentation for 90 days at 62-78° F (17-26° C).
Tertiary fermentation for 3 months.

description:
The following beer recipe is featured in the September/October 2014 issue of Zymurgy magazine. Access this issue along with the archives with Zymurgy Online!
Jose Gutierrez of Rosamond, CA won a gold medal in Category #18: Belgian Strong Ale during the 2014 National Homebrew Competition Final Round in Grand Rapids, MI. Gutierrez’s Belgian Strong Ale was chosen as the best among 408 final round entries in the category.
